The '''2009 flu pandemic in Oceania''', part of an [[epidemic]] in 2009 of a new strain of [[influenza A virus subtype H1N1]] causing what has been commonly called [[swine influenza|swine flu]], has (as of 27 June 2009) afflicted at over 22,000 [[human|people]] in [[Oceania]], with 56 confirmed [[deaths]]. Almost all of the cases in Oceania have been in [[Australia]], where the majority of cases have resulted from internal community spread of the virus. In addition, the government of [[New Zealand]], where most of the remainder of cases in Oceania have occurred, is on high alert for any people travelling into the country with flu-like symptoms. {| Map.svg|thumb|center|{{legend|#000000|Deaths}}{{legend|#cd3412|Confirmed cases}}{{legend|#ffcd00|Suspect cases}}{{legend|Silver|No cases}}]] |} As of July 9, 7,290 cases confirmed in Australia with 20 confirmed deaths.{{cite web |url=http://www.healthemergency.gov.au/internet/healthemergency/publishing.nsf/Content/3F3956D6384E104ACA2575EB00192925/$File/h1n1-update-20090709.pdf |title=National tally of people being tested for Swine Influenza As at 12pm, 9 July 2009 |format=PDF |publisher=Department of Health and Ageing |date=2009-07-09 |accessdate=2009-07-09 }}{{cite web |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601081&sid=atkcOBsG3fck&refer=australia |title=Australia Says Confirmed Swine Flu Cases Rise to 502 (Update2) |date=2009-06-02 |publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.]] |accessdate=2009-06-02}} The alert level has been lifted from "delay" to "contain", giving authorities in all states the option to close schools if students are at risk.{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/05/23/2579007.htm|title=Rudd defends swine flu threat upgrade|date=2009-05-23|work=ABC News|publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation|accessdate=2009-05-23| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090527085158/http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/05/23/2579007.htm| archivedate= 27 May 2009 | deadurl= no}} Australia has a stockpile of 8.7 million doses of [[Tamiflu]] and [[Relenza]].{{cite news |url=http://www.theage.com.au/national/70-australians-tested-for-swine-flu-20090428-alvp.html?page=-1 |title=70 Australians tested for swine flu |publisher=AAP |accessdate=2009-04-28 | location=Melbourne | date=2009-04-29| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090430094929/http://www.theage.com.au/national/70-australians-tested-for-swine-flu-20090428-alvp.html?page=-1| archivedate= 30 April 2009 | deadurl= no}} Airlines have been required to report passengers from the [[Americas]] with influenza symptoms, and nurses have been deployed at international airports. On May 9, the first confirmed case in Australia was reported.{{cite news|title=First confirmed case of swine flu in Australia |publisher=News.com.au |date=2009-05-09 |url=http://www.news.com.au/story/0,27574,25452286-5018988,00.html |accessdate=2009-05-09 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090511005950/http://www.news.com.au/story/0%2C27574%2C25452286-5018988%2C00.html |archivedate=May 11, 2009 |deadurl=yes |df= }} On May 20, four additional cases were reported, one in New South Wales and three in Victoria.{{cite news | title = Sydney has latest cases of swine flu in Australia | publisher = smh.com.au | date = 2009-05-20 | url = http://www.smh.com.au/national/sydney-has-latest-cases-of-swine-flu-in-australia-20090520-bf3r.html | accessdate = 2009-05-20 | first=Jonathan | last=Dart| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090523140358/http://www.smh.com.au/national/sydney-has-latest-cases-of-swine-flu-in-australia-20090520-bf3r.html| archivedate= 23 May 2009 | deadurl= no}}{{cite news | title= Swine flu: three brothers test positive | publisher=theage.com.au | date = 2009-05-20 | url = http://www.theage.com.au/national/swine-flu-three-brothers-test-positive-20090520-bf2q.html | accessdate = 2009-05-20 | location=Melbourne | first1=Mex | last1=Cooper | first2=Nick | last2=Miller| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090521194018/http://www.theage.com.au/national/swine-flu-three-brothers-test-positive-20090520-bf2q.html| archivedate= 21 May 2009 | deadurl= no}} On May 21, an additional case was reported in Victoria. Victorian health authorities close [[Clifton Hill, Victoria|Clifton Hill]] Primary School for two days (initially) after three brothers return to the school from a trip to [[Disneyland]] and are confirmed to have H1N1.{{cite news | title = Swine flu outbreak closes school | publisher = smh.com.au | date = 2009-05-21 | url = http://www.smh.com.au/national/swine-flu-outbreak-closes-school-20090521-bfyw.html | accessdate = 2009-05-21| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090523210800/http://www.smh.com.au/national/swine-flu-outbreak-closes-school-20090521-bfyw.html| archivedate= 23 May 2009 | deadurl= no}} On May 22, cases were reported in South Australia and Victoria, including the first reported cases where the virus was contracted in Australia.{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/05/22/2577971.htm|title=Melbourne boy tests positive to swine flu|work=ABC News|publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation|accessdate=2009-05-22| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090523202055/http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/05/22/2577971.htm| archivedate= 23 May 2009 | deadurl= no}} On May 25, the first confirmed case in Western Australia was reported. On May 26, 3 additional cases were reported in Sydney. The newly confirmed cases involved two children who arrived in Sydney on the cruise ship named [[Pacific Dawn (ship)|Pacific Dawn]] and another child who had recently returned from a trip to the United States. NSW Health issued a directive to the 2000 passengers who arrived in Sydney on the Pacific Dawn requiring that they stay at home for 7 days. On 19 June the first confirmed death from swine flu in Australia was a 26-year-old [[Indigenous Australian|Aboriginal man]] from [[Kiwirrkurra Community, Western Australia|Kiwirrkurra Community]] in the [[Western Desert cultural bloc|Western Desert]] of Western Australia who died in [[Royal Adelaide Hospital]].{{cite news |title=WA man dies from swine flu|first=Daile |last=Pepper| publisher=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |date= 19 June 2009|accessdate = 19 June 2009|url=http://www.smh.com.au/national/wa-man-dies-from-swine-flu-20090619-cq3z.html| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090621123818/http://www.smh.com.au/national/wa-man-dies-from-swine-flu-20090619-cq3z.html| archivedate= 21 June 2009 | deadurl= no}}{{cite web|url=http://www.healthemergency.gov.au/internet/healthemergency/publishing.nsf/Content/news-190609 |title=First Suspected Death from H1N1 Influenza 09 infection |format=PDF |publisher=Department of Health and Ageing |date=2009-06-19 |accessdate=2009-06-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090622222736/http://www.healthemergency.gov.au/internet/healthemergency/publishing.nsf/Content/news-190609 |archivedate=June 22, 2009 }} =={{flag|Fiji}}== Fiji on Wednesday{{When|date=June 2009}} moved to high alert against the swine flu virus, with the authorities admitting the Pacific island nation was not immune to the rapidly spreading global threat.{{cite web |url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-04/29/content_11282228.htm |title= Fiji on high alert against swine flu virus |publisher=|accessdate=2009-04-28| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090503205646/http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-04/29/content_11282228.htm| archivedate= 3 May 2009 | deadurl= no}} On Thursday April 30, 2009, a traveller suspected of being infected by the swine flu virus is under close surveillance at Lautoka Hospital, said the Health Ministry.{{cite web| url= http://www.fijitimes.com/story.aspx?id=120407| title= Fiji records first probable swine flu case| publisher= | accessdate= 2009-04-28| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090502010153/http://www.fijitimes.com/story.aspx?id=120407| archivedate= 2009-05-02| deadurl= yes| df= }} Hours later, the Health Ministry said there were two suspected cases. 2 cases of H1N1 confirmed in Fiji.{{cite web |url=http://www.fijivillage.com/?mod=story&id=30040982b23b41b0558dd72dbc9fb5 |title= 2 suspected cases of Swine Flu travelled to Fiji |publisher=|accessdate=2009-04-28| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090503162710/http://www.fijivillage.com/?mod=story&id=30040982b23b41b0558dd72dbc9fb5| archivedate= 3 May 2009 | deadurl= no}} As of June 30, 2009 there are 10 confirmed cases of swine Flu in Fiji. {{Citation needed|date=July 2009}} On 10 July 2009, a total of 52 cases of swine flu were confirmed in the nation. {{Citation needed|date=July 2009}} =={{flag|French Polynesia}}== [[French Polynesia]] has reported no cases of swine flu so far.{{cite news |title=No swine flu cases in French Polynesia |url=http://www.tahitipresse.pf/index.cfm?snav=see&presse=27384&lang=2 |agency=[[Agence Tahitienne de Presse]] |date=2009-04-28 |accessdate=2009-04-29 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090504024542/http://www.tahitipresse.pf/index.cfm?snav=see&presse=27384&lang=2 |archivedate=4 May 2009 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Officials installed a [[thermal imaging camera]] on April 27, 2009, at [[Faa'a International Airport]] in [[Tahiti]] to screen all arriving international passengers. French Polynesia has 48,000 [[Tamiflu]] [[Antiviral drug|anti-viral]] treatments available in case of an outbreak, and more can be flown into Tahiti within twenty-four hours. On June 10, 2009, French Polynesia reported its first confirmed case in the islands.{{cite news |title=BULLETIN EPIDEMIOLOGIQUE GRIPPE A(H1N1) |url=http://www.invs.sante.fr/display/?doc=surveillance/grippe_dossier/index_h1n1.htm |agency=Institut de veille sanitaire |date=2009-06-10 |accessdate=2009-06-11}} =={{flagicon|Indonesia|}} [[Indonesia]]== {{Further information|2009 flu pandemic in Asia#Indonesia{{!}}2009 flu pandemic in Asia}} =={{flag|Marshall Islands}}== As of July 20, there were 4 confirmed cases in the Marshall Islands.{{cite web|url=http://www.rnzi.com/pages/news.php?op=read&id=47721 |title=Marshall Islands confirms its first swine flu cases |date=2009-07-14 |publisher=Radio New Zealand International |accessdate=2009-07-15 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jhHEHtV4?url=http://www.rnzi.com/pages/news.php?op=read&id=47721 |archivedate=2009-09-11 |deadurl=no |df= }} =={{flag|New Caledonia|1853}}== On June 2, 2009 the authorities in New Caledonia refused to allow the cruise-ship from Australia, the ''Dawn Princess'' to dock because five patients on board had flu-like symptoms.[http://www.brisbanetimes.com.au/national/cruise-ship-dawn-princess-cleared-of-swine-flu-20090604-bw8q.html ''Brisbane Times'', June 4, 2009] =={{flag|New Zealand}}== [[File:H1N1 New Zealand confirmed cases.png|thumb|left|New Zealand
{{legend|#CC3300|50+ Confirmed cases}}{{legend|#FF6666|5-49 Confirmed cases}}{{legend|#FF9999|1-4 Confirmed cases}}]] [[File:Swine Flu map NZ.PNG|thumb|right|New Zealand
{{legend|#000000|Deaths}} {{legend|#FF0000|Confirmed cases}}]] {{Main article|2009 flu pandemic in New Zealand}} The impact in New Zealand has been unprecedented, with school closures across the country. There have been only isolated instances of community transmission.{{cite web|url=http://www.moh.govt.nz/moh.nsf/indexmh/influenza-a-h1n1-update-seventyeven-160609 |date=2009-06-16 |title=Media Release 16 June 2009 Influenza A (H1N1) Swine Flu - Update Seventy-seven |publisher=New Zealand Ministry of Health |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jhHDBPtr?url=http://www.moh.govt.nz/moh.nsf/indexmh/influenza-a-h1n1-update-seventyeven-160609 |archivedate=11 September 2009 |deadurl=no |accessdate=2009-07-22 |df= }} On Saturday [[ANZAC day|25 April]] 2009 ten students from [[Rangitoto College]], a secondary school in [[North Shore City]], [[Auckland]], exhibited influenza symptoms on returning from a three-week language trip to Mexico. All 22 students and three accompanying teachers from the trip and those in close contact with them were placed in voluntary home isolation and treated with [[oseltamivir]]. The ten students tested positive for an influenza A virus,{{cite web|url=http://www.3news.co.nz/News/Students-likely-to-have-swine-flu/tabid/209/articleID/101271/cat/87/Default.aspx|title=Students likely to have swine flu|publisher=[[TV3 (New Zealand)|TV3 (3 News)]]|date=2009-04-06|accessdate=2009-04-26}}{{cite news|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10568751|title=NZ students in swine flu scare|publisher=[[The New Zealand Herald]]|date=April 26, 2009| accessdate= 7 June 2009 }} with three of them later testing positive for swine flu.{{cite web|url=http://www.moh.govt.nz/moh.nsf/indexmh/results-of-h1n1-swine-flu-testing-280409 |title=RESULTS OF H1N1 (Swine flu) testing |publisher=Moh.govt.nz |date= |accessdate=2009-04-28| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090429231435/http://www.moh.govt.nz/moh.nsf/indexmh/results-of-h1n1-swine-flu-testing-280409| archivedate= 29 April 2009 | deadurl= no}} The symptoms were reportedly mild and all affected individuals have since recovered.{{cite web|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10569271&pnum=0|title=Swine flu: Airline passengers held in transit over flu concerns|date=2009-04-28|publisher=New Zealand Herald| accessdate= 7 June 2009 }} New Zealand has had a well-developed Influenza Pandemic action plan since 2006.{{cite web|url=http://www.moh.govt.nz/moh.nsf/indexmh/nz-influenza-pandemic-action-plan-2006 |title=New Zealand Influenza Pandemic Action Plan - 2006 |publisher=New Zealand Ministry of Health |date=September 2006 |accessdate=2009-04-28 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090428171812/http://www.moh.govt.nz/moh.nsf/indexmh/nz-influenza-pandemic-action-plan-2006 |archivedate=28 April 2009 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Following this plan New Zealand immediately upgraded its influenza pandemic alert status to code yellow.{{cite web|url=http://www.nzdoctor.co.nz/news?article=0977f2fa-2d51-45f6-b8dc-82b5fcabcf03 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090429231157/http://www.nzdoctor.co.nz/news?article=0977f2fa-2d51-45f6-b8dc-82b5fcabcf03 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2009-04-29 |title=Daily News |publisher=New Zealand Doctor Online |date=2009-04-27 |accessdate=2009-04-28 |df= }} The national stockpile of 1.4 million doses of oseltamivir was released to regional health authorities. The initial response as specified in the Pandemic Action Plan is a policy of border control and cluster control via voluntary quarantine and treatment of contacts with oseltamivir. As of May 24, this policy appears to have been successful in preventing the Mexican Flu from spreading within New Zealand. New Zealand had about 48,000 influenza cases in the 2008 flu season – 42% of which were type A – and approximately 100 deaths a year directly attributed to influenza viruses.{{cite news|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10569496 |title=Big jump in suspected swine flu cases |work=National |publisher=New Zealand Herald |location=Auckland |first=Jacqueline |last=Smith |author2=Associated Press |date= 2009-04-29 |accessdate=2009-04-30}} As of July 21, there were 2,255 confirmed cases and 10 deaths. The Ministry Of Health changed plan from 'Containment' to 'Care in the Community'.{{cite web|title=Influenza A (H1N1) Swine Flu - Update 110 |url=http://www.moh.govt.nz/moh.nsf/indexmh/influenza-a-h1n1-update-110-190709?Open |work= |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jhHEguan?url=http://www.moh.govt.nz/moh.nsf/indexmh/influenza-a-h1n1-update-110-190709?Open |archivedate=2009-09-11 |deadurl=no |accessdate=2009-07-22 |df= }} =={{flag|Palau}}== Palau has issued a health alert for swine flu. Health Minister Dr. Stevenson Kuartei told reporters that although there is no reported case in Palau, a Task Force has been convened to increase screening of passengers entering the country.{{cite web|url=http://www.mvarietynews.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=16553:palau-on-health-alert-for-swine-flu-&catid=17:palau-news&Itemid=5|title=Palau on health alert for swine flu |publisher=|date= 2009-04-30|accessdate=2009-04-30}} On July 5, Palau confirmed its first case. =={{flag|Papua New Guinea}}== [[File:H1N1 Papua New Guinea.svg|thumb|right|250px|Papua New Guinea
{{legend|#000000|Deaths}}{{legend|#FF0000|Confirmed cases}} {{legend|#FFA900|Unconfirmed or suspected cases}}]] On June 15, a young [[Port Moresby]] adult has contracted the Disease. Dr Mathias Sapuri said they are doing all they can to try to limit the spread of the virus. The process of the step up of clinical surveillance in the country has been picked up by most health facilities throughout the country now. We are taking swab tests and are making clinical judgments on swine flu, to get on to the Tamiflu treatment. Mathias Sapuri said health staff are also visiting the provinces to bring medication and test kits to them, and to help with their preparedness.{{cite web|url=http://www.avianflutalk.com/forum_posts.asp?TID=23695&PID=187950#187950 |title=Papua New Guinea and Fiji coping with first confirmed swine flu cases - From Radio New Zealand |publisher= |accessdate=2009-06-18 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jhHDylxI?url=http://www.avianflutalk.com/forum_posts.asp?TID=23695&PID=187950 |archivedate=2009-09-11 |deadurl=no |df= }} As of July 2, 2009, only one case is confirmed in the country =={{flag|Samoa}}== On June 15, Health Authorities confirmed the first case of flu. An Australian young student tested positive.{{cite web|url=http://www.rnzi.com/pages/news.php?op=read&id=47175|title=Samoa confirms positive swine flu test for Australian student |publisher=|date= 2009-06-15|accessdate=2009-06-15| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090618010600/http://www.rnzi.com/pages/news.php?op=read&id=47175| archivedate= 18 June 2009 | deadurl= no}} =={{flag|Solomon Islands}}== A multi-sectoral task force has been activated by the Solomon Islands Ministry of Health to deal with the swine influenza virus. Permanent Secretary of the Ministry of Health and Medical Service Lester Ross said a task force is managing the Solomon Island Ministry of health's response to recent threat of swine flu epidemic.{{cite news |first=|last=|title= Solomon Islands issues swine flu alert |url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-04/30/content_11287192.htm |work=|publisher=|date=2009-04-29|accessdate=2009-04-30| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090503205708/http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-04/30/content_11287192.htm| archivedate= 3 May 2009 | deadurl= no}} On June 15, Health Authorities confirmed the first case of flu.{{cite news|first=|last=|title='Solomon Islands may lack capacity to deal with H1N1 outbreak' says official|url=http://australianetworknews.com/stories/200906/2598896.htm?desktop|work=|publisher=|date=2009-06-15|accessdate=2009-06-15|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090616122100/http://australianetworknews.com/stories/200906/2598896.htm?desktop|archive-date=2009-06-16|dead-url=yes|df=}} =={{flag|Tokelau}}== Most supplies and food shipments to Tokelau are sent by ferry from the neighboring country of [[Samoa]]. The [[Samoa Health Ministry]] had cancelled all travel to Tokelau until further notice as a precaution against the introduction of swine flu to the Tokelauan population.{{cite news |first=|last=|title=Samoa Health Ministry cancels travel to Tokelau|url=http://www.rnzi.com/pages/news.php?op=read&id=46498 |work=[[Radio New Zealand International]] |publisher=|date=2009-05-11|accessdate=2009-05-11| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090618220258/http://www.rnzi.com/pages/news.php?op=read&id=46498| archivedate= 18 June 2009 | deadurl= no}} The Operations Manager for the Tokelau Office in [[Apia, Samoa]], [[Makalio Ioane]], confirmed that some ferry travel would still be allowed to Tokelau, but the ship's crew would not be allowed to leave the boat or dock in Tokelau. The boat will be off loaded without any physical contact with the Tokelauan population. No cases of swine flu have been reported on either Tokelau or Samoa, so the cessation of travel to Tokelau is considered a precaution. =={{flag|Tonga}}== Tonga has set up an Emergency Taskforce and is performing screen checks at its International Airport for passengers experiencing influenza symptoms, most importantly from flights originating from Los Angeles. In Early July Tonga confirmed its first case of Swine flu and on July 21 its first death.{{cite web|title=Tonga Broadcasting - Tonga Reports It's First Death From Swine Flu |url=http://69.64.79.247/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=1907&Itemid=57 |date=21 July 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jhHLRzn8?url=http://69.64.79.247/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=1907&Itemid=57 |archivedate=11 September 2009 |deadurl=yes |accessdate=2009-07-22 |df= }} =={{flag|Nauru}}== One suspected case of swine flu has been identified in Nauru. Travelers entering Nauru are now screened for influenza symptoms, most importantly from flights originating from North America.{{Citation needed|date=April 2009}} =={{flag|Vanuatu}}== Travelers entering the country via [[Santo-Pekoa International Airport]] and [[Bauerfield International Airport]] are now being screened using body heat detection before being allowed to exit the airport's gates. 1st case confirm in Vanuatu.{{Citation needed|date=June 2009}} ==Timeline== {| class="wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto" ! style="background:#ddf"|2009 ! '''99Rise''' is a [[Progressivism in the United States|progressive]] [[social movement organization]] founded in 2012, that aims to "reclaim our democracy from the domination of big money."<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.99rise.org/about|title=About 99Rise|newspaper=99Rise|access-date=2016-10-22}}</ref> According to their website, 99rise's 10 principles are: nonviolence, strategic unity, common message, [[Decentralization|decentralized]] structure, democratic cooperation, inclusion, [[Pluralism (political theory)|pluralism]], leadership as service, voluntarism, and open affiliation.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.99rise.org/our_principles|title=Our Principles|newspaper=99Rise|access-date=2016-10-22}}</ref> Structure wise, 99rise is a decentralized organization with distributed leadership stretching across the United States. 99Rise puts activists and organizers through 2-day detailed DNA trainings, Online Basic Trainings, and monthly Online Orientations in order to equip each member with the tools needed to continue to spread their organization's message.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=http://www.99rise.org/who|title=Who Are We?|newspaper=99Rise|access-date=2016-10-22}}</ref> Since the formation of the movement, 99rise members have garnered media attention by protesting during [[Supreme Court of the United States|Supreme Court]] hearings and by interrupting [[Donald Trump]] at the 2016 GOP debate.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/volokh-conspiracy/wp/2015/04/06/99rise-protesters-charged-with-class-a-misdemeanor-in-federal-court/|title=99Rise protesters charged with Class A misdemeanor in federal court|website=Washington Post|access-date=2016-10-27}}</ref><ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://time.com/4150974/republican-debate-donald-trump-heckler/|title=Watch Donald Trump Get Heckled by an Anti-Big-Money Protester|last=Alter|first=Charlotte|website=TIME.com|access-date=2016-10-27}}</ref>
== Strategy == 99Rise plans on achieving their goal to reclaim democracy from the domination of big money through a five phase approach:<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/volokh-conspiracy/wp/2015/04/02/reader-poll-whats-the-proper-punishment-for-99rise-protesters/|title=Reader poll: What’s the proper punishment for 99Rise protesters?|website=Washington Post|access-date=2016-11-18}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.99rise.org/strategy|title=How do we win?|newspaper=99Rise|access-date=2016-11-18}}</ref> # (Before April 2016) Build the movement. 99Rise prepared each activist through encompassing trainings, team building exercises, and leadership meetings. # (April 2016 - September 2016) Participate in forms of civil disobedience to get the attention of political leadership during the 2016 election. For example, 99Rise disrupted the Supreme Court on April 1, 2015 and Donald Trump at the GOP debate. # (September 2016 - December 2016) Mobilize members to get out and elect representatives and a president who will be their champion for the causes they are fighting for. # (January 2017- December 2017) Hold Congress, the President, and state legislatures accountable when it comes to meeting their demands to reclaim democracy. If the governing bodies do not meet their demands for constitutional and legislative reform, then participate in forms of civil disobedience and/or mass noncooperation. # (January 2017 - November 2018) Monitor and enforce the reform agenda until it is enacted. Further escalation of civil disobedience if necessary.
== Leadership == Kai Newkirk is the co-founder and most visible member of 99Rise.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bustle.com/articles/130178-who-was-donald-trumps-heckler-at-the-gop-debate-kai-newkirk-disrupts-for-an-important-reason|title=Who Was Donald Trump's Heckler At The GOP Debate? Kai Newkirk Disrupts For An Important Reason|last=Yang|first=Melissah|access-date=2016-11-18}}</ref> While Newkirk understands the difficulties of 99rise's mission, he stresses that there are important smaller victories that can be achieved to restore some integrity back into the political process. Newkirk wants to push for the adoption of disclosure laws to address the problem of dark money and wants to create a democracy voucher system which would give a tax credit to voters to let every voter direct $50 or $100 to a candidate of their choosing. He believes that these two victories would be a step in the right direction towards achieving their ultimate goal of reclaiming democracy from the power of big money.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://content.ebscohost.com/ContentServer.asp?T=P&P=AN&K=101534597&S=R&D=f5h&EbscoContent=dGJyMMTo50Sep7Y4zOX0OLCmr06ep7RSsqu4TK6WxWXS&ContentCustomer=dGJyMPGnsEq0qbVIuePfgeyx43zx|title=Is there a pathway to ending corporate rule in America?|last=Engler|first=Mark|date=April 2015|work=Issue 481, p33, 1p|access-date=November 15, 2016|via=EBSCOHost}}</ref>
== Actions ==
=== Supreme Court Hearing Protests ===
==== Jan 21, 2015 ==== A group of seven 99rise activists protested during a Supreme Court Hearing. They chose this day to disrupt the court because they were condemning the ruling in the Citizens United case which happened five years ago from this day. In a report following the incident, 99Rise members also noted that a Princeton study concluded the average American had "near-zero, statistically non-significant impact upon public policy."<ref>Martin Gilens and Benjamin I. Page, "Testing Theories of American Politics: Elites, Interest Groups, and Average Citizens". Princeton University. Retrieved 2016-11-18.</ref> They rationalized that there disturbance of the court was one way they could make an impact, or draw attention towards public policy that they find unjust. Immediately following the disruption, the activists were escorted out of the courtroom and were charged with making a harangue or oration.<ref name="auto">{{Cite journal|last=Bellew|first=Chelsea Elizabeth|date=2015-12-04|title=Combating Corruption in Campaign Finance in the United States: Why a Grass Roots Approach Is the Only Solution|ssrn=2699349|location=Rochester, NY|publisher=Social Science Research Network}}</ref> The individuals charged were Andrew Batcher, Irandira Gonzales, Margaret Johnson, Alexandra Flores-Quilty, Katherine Philipson, Curt Ries, and Mary Zeiser. The 8th member in the courtroom, Ryan Clayton, allegedly used a concealed camera to film the incident. It is still unclear as to what penalty Clayton will receive.<ref name="auto" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/lauren-windsor/exclusive-video-citizens-_b_6542166.html|title=EXCLUSIVE VIDEO: Citizens United Protest Inside the Supreme Court|last=Producer|first=Lauren Windsor Executive|last2=Undercurrent|first2=The|date=2015-01-26|website=The Huffington Post|access-date=2016-11-19}}</ref>
==== April 1, 2015 ==== A group of five 99rise activists protested during another [[Supreme Court of the United States|Supreme Court]] hearing. The 99rise members stood up and said, "We rise to demand democracy. One person, one vote".<ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=http://www.99rise.org/supreme_court_civil_disobedience|title=Watch: Video From Inside Supreme Court Disruption|newspaper=99Rise|access-date=2016-10-27}}</ref> Immediately after, they were tackled and arrested.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://heinonline.org/HOL/LandingPage?handle=hein.journals/joolaw6&div=16&id=&page=|title=A Year in the Life of the Supreme Court (Almanac Excerpts)|journal= 6 Journal of Law |year=2016|access-date=2016-11-07}}</ref> They now face two charges: picketing with the intent of interfering with or obstructing the administration of justice and making a harangue or oration.<ref name=":1" /> The date that they protested, April 1, 2015, is also of significance because it is the one year anniversary of the McCutcheon vs FEC Supreme Court ruling. The ruling "struck down the aggregate limits on the amount an individual may contribute during a two-year period to all federal candidates, parties and political action committees combine."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.fec.gov/law/litigation/McCutcheon.shtml|title=McCutcheon|website=www.fec.gov|access-date=2016-10-27}}</ref> 99rise contends that this ruling gave the 1% even more power to control our democracy through political donations by getting rid of the previously held restriction of $123,400 that one may contribute to a candidate, PACs, or parties.<ref name=":3" />
=== GOP Debate Interruption === During the 2016 GOP debate, Kai Newkirk, one of the cofounders of 99rise, stood up and interrupted Donald Trump.<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=http://www.mediaite.com/online/watch-protestor-heckles-donald-trump-at-cnn-republican-debate/|title=WATCH: Protestor Heckles Donald Trump at CNN Republican Debate (UPDATED)|website=www.mediaite.com|access-date=2016-10-27}}</ref> While there are conflicting reports as to what Newkirk said, sources claim he spoke out for fair elections rather than billionaire controlled ones.<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":4" /> He was immediately removed from the venue following the disruption.
=== March for Democracy Across California === On May 17, 2014, members of 99rise began their 480-mile journey from LA City Hall to the State Capital in Sacramento, California.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.newsreview.com/sacramento/small-money-strikes-back-with/content?oid=14008309|title=Small money strikes back with the 99Rise movement - Bites - Opinions - July 10, 2014|website=Sacramento News & Review|access-date=2016-10-27}}</ref> The march called for three tangible changes to legislation:<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.occupy.com/article/99rise-leads-california-march-south-north-end-corruption-money-politics|title=99Rise Leads California March, South to North, To End Corruption Of Money In Politics|date=2014-05-28|newspaper=Occupy.com|access-date=2016-10-27}}</ref> # Pass an amendment that stops big money influence on the American political system. # Pass Senate Bill 1272 (SB1272) - Allow California voters the chance to collaborate and propose such an amendment as stated above, and the California legislature to ratify it by passing a Senate bill. # Pass the [[DISCLOSE Act|Disclose Act]] - Stop anonymous money in elections.

{{about|inhabitants of the Dominican Republic of African descent|inhabitants of the Commonwealth of Dominica of African descent|Afro-Dominican (Dominica)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2017}} {{Infobox ethnic group |group = Afro-Dominicans | pop = '''1,029,535'''
Dominicans of full or predominant African ancestry{{cite book|last=Moya Pons|first=Frank|authorlink=Frank Moya Pons|editor=Frank Moya Pons|title=Historia de la República Dominicana|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Wor3UqsHkToC&pg=PA50|accessdate=14 July 2017|volume=II|year=2010|publisher=CSIC Press|isbn=978-84-00-09240-5|pages=50–52|chapter=Evolución de la población dominicana}}
10.9% of the Dominican population (1960 census){{cite book|title=Cuarto Censo Nacional de Población, 1960|date=1966|publisher=Oficina Nacional de Estadísticas|location=Santo Domingo|page=32}}{{#tag:ref|The electoral census of 1996 estimated the proportion of black people at 4.26 percent. An estimate from 2009 was as high as 30 percent of the population.{{cite book|format=PDF|last1=Sención Villalona|first1=Augusto|editor1-last=Haché|editor1-first=Juana|title=Historia dominicana: desde los aborígenes hasta la Guerra de Abril|trans-title=Dominican History: From the aboriginals to the War of April|language=es|date=December 2010|website=Archivo General de la Nación|publication-place=Santo Domingo, D.N|isbn=978-9945-074-10-9|url=http://www.agn.gov.do/sites/default/files/publicaciones/vol.118._historiadominicana._augusto_sencioncoord..pdf|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141129003628/http://www.agn.gov.do/sites/default/files/publicaciones/vol.118._historiadominicana._augusto_sencioncoord..pdf|archivedate=29 November 2014}}|group="nb"|name=""}} |popplace = Chiefly in '''[[Elías Piña Province|Elías Piña]]''', '''[[San Pedro de Macorís Province|San Pedro de Macorís]]''', '''[[Santo Domingo Province|Santo Domingo]]''', and '''[[San Cristóbal Province|San Cristóbal]]'''; also in [[Dajabón Province|Dajabón]], [[Pedernales Province|Pedernales]], [[Independencia Province|Independencia]], [[La Romana Province|La Romana]] and [[Hato Mayor Province|Hato Mayor]] |langs = majority [[Dominican Spanish]] {{·}} minority [[Caribbean English]] ([[Samaná English]]) |rels = [[Dominican Vudú]], [[Roman Catholicism]], [[Protestantism]] |related = [[People of the Dominican Republic|Dominican people]], other [[Afro-Latin Americans]], [[Afro-Haitians]] }} '''Afro-Dominicans''' are Dominicans of predominant Black African ancestry. They represent 5.26% of the [[Dominican Republic]]'s population, according to the 1996 electoral census based on Dominican identity cards data, or 10.9% of the Dominican population, according to the 1960 population census (the last one in which race was queried). The majority of Black Dominicans descend from [[West Africa]]ns and [[Central Africa]]ns who arrived from the sixteenth to the early nineteenth century as a result of [[Atlantic slave trade|slavery]], while many others descend from black freedman who came from the [[United States]] during the 19th century and black immigrants from the [[Commonwealth Caribbean|Anglo]] and [[French West Indies|French Caribbean]] islands who arrived during the 20th century. Currently there are also many black migrants, particularly from [[Haiti]],{{cite news|author=Aníbal de Castro|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/dominican-republic-has-a-clear-respectful-immigration-policy/2013/11/15/baca2d06-4d56-11e3-bf60-c1ca136ae14a_story.html|title=Dominican Republic has a clear, respectful immigration policy|publisher=Washington Post|date=15 November 2013|accessdate=13 January 2016}}{{cite web|format=PDF|url=http://www.oas.org/atip/Regional%20Reports/MigrationintheCaribbean.pdf|title=Migration in the Caribbean: Haiti, the Dominican Republic and Beyond|first=James|last=Ferguson|publisher=Minority Groups International|publication-place=London|date=July 2003|accessdate=13 July 2017|isbn=1-904584-07-1}}{{cite web|first=Bryan|last=Schaaf|url=http://haitiinnovation.org/en/2009/05/21/haiti-and-dominican-republic-same-island-different-worlds|title=Haiti and the Dominican Republic: Same Island, Different Worlds|publisher=Haiti Innovation.org|date=21 May 2009|accessdate=13 January 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090525233933/http://haitiinnovation.org/en/2009/05/21/haiti-and-dominican-republic-same-island-different-worlds|archivedate=25 May 2009}} who can be included within the Afro-Dominican demographics if they were born in the country or have [[Dominican Republic|Dominican]] naturalization. Black Dominicans make up a significant minority of the country's population, but there is a lack of recent official data and it is not possible to quantify their numbers because the National Office of Statistics (ONE) does not release racial data since 1960, though the Central Electoral Board still collected racial data until 2014. According to a 2011 survey by [[Latinobarómetro]], 26% of the Dominicans surveyed identified themselves as black.{{cite web|url=https://www.scribd.com/document/70688598/INFORME-DE-LATINOBAROMETRO-2011|title=Informe Latinobarómetro 2011: Tabla Nº16: Raza a la que pertenece por país|trans-title=Latinobarómetro Report 2011: Table Nº16: Race to which responder belongs by country|language=es|publisher=Corporación Latinobarómetro|page=58|date=28 October 2012|accessdate=13 July 2017}} ==Census== Black ({{Lang-es|Negro}}, ''colloq.'' Moreno) has historically been a part of the official [[racial classification]] system of the [[Dominican Republic]]. However the census bureau decided to not use racial classification in the 1970 census. The [[Cédula de Identidad y Electoral|Dominican identity card]] (issued by the ''Junta Central Electoral'') used to categorise people as yellow, white, Indian, and black,{{cite journal|last1=De León|first1=Viviano|title=RD será de negros, blancos y mulatos : Reforma electoral eliminaría el color indio|journal=[[Listín Diario]]|date=11 November 2011|url=http://www.listindiario.com/la-republica/2011/11/11/210557/RD-sera-de-negros-blancos-y-mulatos|accessdate=25 October 2014|language=Spanish}} in 2011 the Junta planned to replace Indian with mulatto in a new ID card with biometric data that was under development, but in 2014 when it released the new ID card, it decided to just drop racial categorisation, the old ID card expired on 10 January 2015.{{cite news|author1=Néstor Medrano|author2=Ramón Pérez Reyes|title=La JCE acelera cedulación en instituciones del país|url=http://www.listindiario.com/la-republica/2014/4/23/319202/La-JCE-acelera-cedulacion-en-instituciones-del-pais|accessdate=9 April 2015|publisher=Listín Diario|date=23 April 2014|language=Spanish|quote=Entre las novedades del nuevo documento no se establece como se hacía anteriormente el color de la piel de la persona, ya que, la misma fotografía consigna ese elemento.}}{{cite news|author1=Néstor Medrano|title=La cédula vieja vence hoy; miles acuden a centros JCE|url=http://www.listindiario.com/la-republica/2015/1/10/352025/La-cedula-vieja-vence-hoy-miles-acuden-a-centros-JCE|accessdate=9 April 2015|publisher=Listín Diario|date=10 January 2015|language=Spanish}} The Ministry of Public Works and Communications uses racial classification in the [[driver’s license]], being white, mestizo, mulatto, black, and yellow the categories used. == History == '''Early years: transition from Indigenous to African forced labor''' [[File:Spanish Caribbean Islands in the American Viceroyalties 1600.png|thumb|right|280px|Spanish Caribbean with The Captaincy General of Santo Domingo in the center.]] In 1502 (or 1503), the [[Monarchy of Spain|Spanish Crown]] finally acquiesced to the [[Conquistador|colonists]]' demands for enslaved Africans. The [[Captaincy General of Santo Domingo|Santo Domingo colony]], the only European possession yet in America, had already produced a devastating effect on the [[Taíno|Taino]], [[Lucayan people|Lucayan]] (Arawaks), and [[Island Caribs|Kalinga]] (Caribs) populations. A decade of intense exploitation and deadly waves of plagues had reduced the indigenous populations to levels that even the Spaniards considered dangerous. As the Hispaniolan Tainos (and [[Cigüayos]]) declined during the first couple of years of colonization, the [[Christopher Columbus]] Administration had gone against the wishes of [[Isabella I of Castile|Isabel I of Castile]] and had begun the first European slave trade on the western side of [[Atlantic Ocean|Atlantic]]. Raids that cleared out from Santo Domingo under the disguise of pacification and to evangelize nearby islanders had brought in other Amerindians to the colony. They were a large number of enslaved Lucayos from the Bahamas and Kalingas from the eastern islands. Now toiling alongside native Hispaniolans, these war captives became the first enslaved foreign workers on the island of [[Hispaniola|Aytí]], one of the indigenous names for the island that Columbus called Hispaniola. By the turn of the century, not even the captured neighbors could supply the labor demands of the mines and plantations. Rudimentary mining techniques and the always backbreaking mass-production of food-stuff required an ever-growing number of coerced workers. Expanding the colonization project to Puerto Rico and requesting the Crown permission to purchase enslaved Africans were the only two solutions colonists seemed capable of conceiving. Ferdinand I of Aragon, widowed and freed from Isabel's more cautious hand, granted both wishes to the embattled colonists in the Indies. It was never a liberal expansion nor an open trade, however. Though unrestrained by religious piety, Ferdinand, who was the ideal Prince in Machiavelli's imagination, was wary in the extreme of potential Conquistador-owned kingdoms (medieval style) in his new possessions, and of slave rebellions in the colonies. So, the first group of enslaved Africans to arrive at the [[Ozama River]] were not [[Piezas de Indias]] purchased from the Portuguese traders, but a select group of seasoned [[Black Ladinos]].{{cite web|url=http://www.refworld.org/cgi-bin/texis/vtx/rwmain?page=country&category=&publisher=&type=COUNTRYPROF&coi=DOM&rid=&docid=4954ce1923&skip=0|title=World Directory of Minorities and Indigenous Peoples – Dominican Republic|work=Minority Rights Group International – MRGI|year=2007|accessdate=13 January 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://old.antislavery.org/breakingthesilence/slave_routes/slave_routes_dominicanrepublic.shtml|title=Slave Routes: Dominican Republic|publisher=Antislavery.org|accessdate=3 February 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121214054119/http://old.antislavery.org/breakingthesilence/slave_routes/slave_routes_dominicanrepublic.shtml|archivedate=14 December 2012}} The profit too was meant to stay within his kingdom. Indian resistances, flights, and diseases, however, forced the crown to open the market to thousands of bozales, enslaved Africans directly from the continent.{{cite book|author=José Andrés-Gallego|title=La esclavitud en la América española|trans-title=Slavery in Spanish America|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2s7KNZsq7bsC&pg=PT19|accessdate=14 January 2016|year=2010|publisher=Encuentro|language=es|isbn=978-84-9920-504-5|page=19}} In 1522, the first major slave rebellion was led by 20 Senegalese Muslims of [[Wolof people|Wolof]] origin, in an ingenio (sugar factory) east of the [[Captaincy General of Santo Domingo|Santo Domingo]] colony. Many of the insurgents fled to the mountains and established what would become the first autonomous African [[Maroon (people)|Maroon]] community in America. With the success of this revolt, slave revolts continued and leaders emerged among the African slaves, including people already baptized Christian by the Spanish, as was the case of Juan Vaquero, Diego de Guzmán and Diego del Campo. The rebellions and subsequent escapes led to the establishment of African communities in the southwest, north and east of the island, including the first communities of African ex-slaves in western Hispaniola that was Spanish administered until 1697, when it was sold to France and became [[Saint-Domingue]] (modern-day Haiti). This caused some concern among slaveholders and contributed to the Spanish emigration to other places. Even as sugarcane increased profitability in the island, the number of escaped Africans continued to rise, mixing with [[Taíno people|Taíno]] people of these regions, and by 1530, Maroon bands were considered dangerous to the Spanish colonists, who traveled in large armed groups outside the plantations and left the mountainous regions to the Maroons (until 1654 with the conquest of [[Jamaica]] by the [[Privateer|Corsairs]] of British Admiral [[William Penn]] and general [[Robert Venables]]). With the discovery of precious metals in South America, the Spanish abandoned their migration to the island of Hispaniola to emigrate to South America and Mexico in order to get rich, for they did not find much wealth there. Thus, they also abandoned the slave trade to the island, which led to the collapse of the colony into poverty. Still, during those years, slaves were used to build a cathedral that in time became the most oldest in the Americas. They build the monastery, first hospital and the [[Alcázar de Colón]], and the ''Puerta de las Lamentaciones'' ({{lang-es|Gate of Mercy}}). In the 1540s, Spanish authorities ordered the African slaves building a wall to defend the city from attacks by pirates who ravaged the islands. [[File:Brunias cropped detail.jpg|thumb|280px|''"Free Women of Color with their Children and Servants in a Landscape"'', oil painting, Agostino Brunias.]] After 1700, with the arrival of new Spanish colonists, the African slave trade resumed. However, as industry moved from sugar to livestock, racial and caste divisions became less important, eventually leading to a blend of cultures—Spanish, African, and indigenous—which would form the basis of national identity for Dominicans.{{cite web|author=P. J. Ferbel|url=http://www.suncaribbean.net/rd_laisla_tiempo_preist_tainos_cultura.htm|title=La sobrevivencia de la cultura Taína en la República Dominicana|trans-title=Survival of the Taino culture in the Dominican Republic|language=es|publisher=suncaribbean.net|date=2002|accessdate=13 January 2016}} It is estimated that the population of the colony in 1777 was 400,000, of which 100,000 were Europeans and [[Criollo people|Criollos]], 60,000 African, 100.000 [[mestizo]], 60,000 [[zambo]] and 100,000 [[mulatto]]. At the end of the eighteenth century, fugitive African slaves from Saint-Domingue, the western French colony of the island fled east to Santo Domingo and formed communities such as San Lorenzo de Los Mina, which is currently part of the "city" of Santo Domingo. Fugitives arrived from other parts of the West Indies as well, especially from the [[Lesser Antilles]], dominated by French, English, Dutch, etc.[http://www.colonialzone-dr.com/people_history-sanchez.html Francisco del Rosario Sánchez One of the Padres de la Patria / Fathers of the Patriotism] – Colonial Zone-Dominican Republic (DR) – Retrieved 3 November 2012. In 1801, Haitian revolutionary leader [[Toussaint Louverture]], abolished slavery in the east of Santo Domingo, freeing about 40,000 slaves, and prompting much of the elite of that part of the island to flee to [[Cuba]] and [[Puerto Rico]]. However, slavery was re-established in 1809 when the Spanish recovered the area. At the same time, the French governor Ferrand imported a second group of Haitian slaves to build the French colonial enclave Puerto Napoleon (Samana).{{cite web|author=Bolívar M. Troncoso Morales|url=http://www.suncaribbean.net/rd_laisla_origen_poblacion.htm|title=Origen de la población dominicana|trans-title=Origin of the Dominican population|language=es|publisher=suncaribbean.net|accessdate=13 January 2016}} Slavery was again abolished in 1822 by Haitian president [[Jean-Pierre Boyer]], during the Haitian [[unification of Hispaniola]] which began in February of that year. In 1824, [[African American]] [[free negro|freed people]] began to arrive under the Haitian administered island, benefiting from the favorable pro-African immigration policy of Boyer since 1822, called the [[Haitian emigration]]. Called the [[Samaná Americans]], they mostly settled in [[Puerto Plata Province]] and the [[Samaná Peninsula]] regions. In 1844, one Afro-Dominicans [[Francisco del Rosario Sánchez]] freed the country along with [[Matías Ramón Mella]] and [[Juan Pablo Duarte]] of the Haitian rule. Between the late nineteenth and early twentieth century, black laborers from the [[British West Indies]] came to work in the sugar plantations on the east of the island. Their descendants are known today by the name of [[Cocolo]]s.{{cite journal|author=Carlos Esteban Deive|url=http://www.jmarcano.com/mipais/cultura/deive.html|title=Notas sobre la cultura Dominicana|trans-title=Notes concerning the culture of the Dominican Republic|language=es|journal=Boletín del Museo del Hombre Dominicano|volume=VIII|issue=12|date=January 1979|accessdate=13 January 2016}} == Origins of the slaves== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="float:right;" |- ! Averages ||align=center| 100.0 |} The slave trade involved nearly all of Africa's west coast inhabitants to be forcibly taken to the new world. Most slaves tended to come from mostly the [[Kongo people|Kongo]] people of West-Central Africa (present-day [[Angola]], [[Republic of Congo]] and the [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]]), along with the [[Igbo people|Igbo]] (originating from west from [[Nigeria]]), [[Yoruba people|Yoruba]], [[Akan people|Akan]] and [[Mandinka people|Mandinka]] tribes. Others African ethnic groups arrived to colonial Santo Domingo during the slavery´s period were: [[Wolof people|Wolof]] (imported from [[Senegal]]), [[Aja people|Aja]] (also called ''[[Arará]]s'' in Santo Domingo and imported from [[Dahomey]], current [[Benin]]), [[Ambundu]] (from the [[Kingdom of Ndongo]], in north Angola), Bran (originating from [[Brong-Ahafo Region]], west from [[Ghana]]), [[Fulbe people|Fulbe]], [[Kalabari tribe|Kalabari]] (originating from slave port from [[Calabar]], in Nigeria), Terranova (slaves bought probably in [[Porto-Novo, Benin]]), Zape (originating from [[Sierra Leone]]), [[Bambara people|Bambara]] and [[Biafada people|Biafada]] (this latter was originating from [[Guinea-Bissau]]) people. The Wolof were imported to Santo Domingo from [[Senegal]] in the first half of the sixteenth century, until the import of this ethnic group was prohibited after his rebellion in 1522. Many of the slaves were also Ajas, usually taken in [[Kingdom of Whydah|Whydah]], Benin. The Ajas arrived in Santo Domingo, were well known for having made religious [[Fraternity|brotherhoods]], integrated exclusively for them, the ''San Cosme'' and ''San Damian''.[https://web.archive.org/web/20130908231035/http://uval.lacoctelera.net/post/2011/04/14/etnias-africanas-la-esclavitud-santo-domingo El solitario de la vega real: Etnias africanas en la esclavitud en Santo Domingo] (The solo of The vega real: Ethnic African slavery in Santo Domingo). Retrieved on 8 February 2012. == Demography == The National Institute of Statistics (INE) does not collect racial data since the Census of 1960.{{cite book|author=Frank Moya Pons|authorlink=Frank Moya Pons|title=Historia de la República Dominicana |volume=2|publisher=CSIC|pages=50–52|location=Santo Domingo|year=2010|language=Spanish}} In that census, the ethnic features were obtained by direct observation of the people registered by the enumerator, without any questions asked. About 73% of the population was classified as [[mestizo]] (note that in the 1920, 1935, 1950 and 1960 censuses referred to mixed-race people as mestizo, never as mulatto), 16% was classified as white, and 11% was classified as black (1,795,000 of people).Fuente: Encuesta Latin American Public Opinion Project, LAPOP,{{cite web|url=http://www.one.gob.do/index.php?module=uploads&func=download&fileId=3876|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130729060352/http://www.one.gob.do/index.php?module=uploads&func=download&fileId=3876|archivedate=29 July 2013|publisher=Oficina Nacional de Estadística|title=La variable étnico racial en los censos de población en la República Dominicana|language=Spanish}} According to scholar Silvio Saillant, "today.' Blacks and mulattos make up nearly 90 percent of the contemporary Dominican population." {{cite journal|url=https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B_q6VhhkczIYd3BXeFdhc1JvMU0/view|title=The Tribulations of Blackness: Stages in Dominican Racial Identity|last=Torres-Saillant|first=Silvio|journal=Latin American Perspectives|year=1998|volume=25|issue=3|pages=126–146|accessdate=13 July 2017}} Dominican Republic is one of the few countries in the world where the majority of the population is made up of [[multiracial]]es predominately European and African. So based on these figures, people who self-identify as being "mixed with Afro-ancestry" are at least 86% of the population, numbering at about 8,518,000 people. Although, most of Black Dominicans are descendants of slaves imported to the country and who speak Spanish, there are also two Afro-communities that have English as their mother tongue: [[Samaná Americans]] and [[Cocolo]]s. Samaná Americans from the [[Samaná Peninsula]], are descendants, of freed slaves from the United States, who entered the country in 1824 when it was under Haitian rule, because of the favorable pro-African immigration policy of Haitian president [[Jean-Pierre Boyer]], constitute the most sizable group of native English speakers in the [[Dominican Republic]].{{cite web|url=http://ahorasecreto.blogspot.com/2012/08/the-dominican-republics-african.html|title=African American – Latino World: The Dominican Republic's African-American Descendants|publisher=ahorasecreto.blogspot.com|accessdate=17 October 2014}}{{cite web|first1=Henry|last1=Louis Gates Jr.|authorlink1=Henry Louis Gates Jr.|first2=Kristin|last2=Britanik|url=http://www.theroot.com/articles/culture/2013/10/dominicans_from_samana.html|title=Dominicans and Black American Roots?|publisher=theroot.com|date=18 October 2013|accessdate=17 October 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141021021640/http://www.theroot.com/articles/culture/2013/10/dominicans_from_samana.html|archivedate=21 October 2014}} Aware of its distinctive heritage, the community, whose singular culture distinguishes them from the rest of Dominicans, refers to itself as Samaná Americans, and is referred to by fellow Dominicans as "los americanos de Samaná". Another Afro-group is the called Cocolo, descendants of those who came to the island from the English-speaking islands in the eastern Caribbean to work in the sugar plantations in the eastern part of the island between the late nineteenth and early twentieth century, they have formed communities in [[San Pedro de Macorís]] and [[La Romana Province|La Romana]]. Its largest population of Afro-people are of Haitian origin, which is also the largest immigrant community in the country and is numbered according to some estimates, to be more than 800,000 people.{{cite news|url=http://www.elmundo.es/america/2010/10/31/noticias/1288556420.html|title=Unos 200.000 haitianos se han quedado ilegalmente en República Dominicana|trans-title=About 200,000 population decreased to 18,772 in the 1950 Census, as an aftermath of the [[Parsley Massacre]]. === Geographic distribution === Though, African ancestry is common throughout the Dominican Republic, today it is more prevalent in eastern areas such as [[San Pedro de Macorís Province|San Pedro de Macorís]], [[La Romana Province|La Romana]], and the [[Samaná Peninsula]], as well as along the Haitian border, particularly the southern parts of the border region; it is least prevalent in the [[Cibao Valley]] (especially within the ''Sierra de Zamba'' region), and to a lesser extent, in some rural communities in [[El Seibo Province|El Seibo]] and [[La Altagracia Province|La Altagracia]] provinces, and the western half of the [[Distrito Nacional|National District]] as well. However, in the 19th and early 20th century, African ancestry was higher in the southwestern region than in the eastern region, due to the impact of the Afro-Antillean and Haitian immigration during the 20th century. [[File:Cocolos in Dominican Republic.PNG|thumb|Dominican Republic’s provinces where people of Antillean, Bahamian, and U.S. ancestry predominates.]] Dominicans of Afro-Antillean and African American ancestry lives concentrated in Puerto Plata, Samaná, Hato Mayor, San Pedro de Macorís, La Romana and El Seibo provinces. Dominicans of Haitian ancestry live scattered across the country, however, communities in the border provinces of Elías Piña and Independence where they predominate among the population, highlighting the presence of [[Association football|European football]] fields, a [[Haiti#Sports|very popular sport in Haiti]]. === Haitian immigration === {{Main article|Haitians in the Dominican Republic}} Haitian immigration is the most important of the immigrations to the Dominican Republic since its independence. ====Overview==== Haiti is more impoverished than the Dominican Republic. So, in 2003, 80% of all Haitians were poor (54% in extreme poverty) and 47.1% were illiterate. The country of nine million people has a fast-growing population, but over two-thirds of the jobs lack the formal workforce. Haiti's GDP per capita was $1,300 in 2008, or less than one-sixth of the Dominican figure.{{cite web|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/ha.html|title=Haiti: Economy overview|work=CIA World Factbook|accessdate=13 January 2016}} As a result, hundreds of thousands of Haitians have migrated to the Dominican Republic, with some estimates of 800,000 Haitians in the country,{{cite news|first=Diógenes|last=Pina|url=http://www.ipsnews.net/2007/03/dominican-republic-deport-thy-darker-skinned-neighbour/|title=Dominican Republic: Deport Thy (Darker-Skinned) Neighbour|publisher=Ipsnews.net|date=21 March 2007|accessdate=13 July 2017}} while others believe they are more than a million. Usually working in low paid and unskilled in building construction, household cleaning, and in plantations. Children of illegal Haitian immigrants are often [[Statelessness|stateless]] and they are denied services, as their parents are denied Dominican nationality, and therefore are considered transient residents, due to their illegal status and undocumented, and children often have to choose only Haitian nationality.{{cite news|url=http://www.caribbeannetnews.com/cgi-script/csArticles/articles/000052/005242.htm|title=Dominican Republic, Haiti, and the United States: Protect rights, reduce statelessness|publisher=Caribbean Net News|agency=Reuters|date=19 January 2007|deadurl=y|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080708193320/http://www.caribbeannetnews.com/cgi-script/csArticles/articles/000052/005242.htm|archivedate=8 July 2008}} A large number of Haitian women, often arriving with several health problems, cross the border to Dominican soil during their last weeks of pregnancy to obtain necessary medical care for childbirth, since Dominican public hospitals cannot deny medical services based on nationality or legal status. Statistics from a hospital in Santo Domingo report that over 22% of births are to Haitian mothers. ====History==== Historically, Haiti was wealthier than the Dominican Republic. However, the lack of free lands in Haiti, as land was held by a small group of landlords, motivated Haitian peasants to settle in the borderland region, within the Dominican Republic. Through the years, especially after 1899, the Haitian government claimed the territory populated by Haitians, and under a treaty in 1929 several towns and cities in Central Hispaniola officially became Haitian, comprising 4,572 km2. A Dominican census in 1935 revealed that 3.6% of the population was Haitian. In 1936, the Haitian government claimed more territory and the Dominican Republic ceded another 1,628 km2 to Haiti; the next year, the Dominican dictatorship ordered the ''Dominicanization of the border'' ({{lang-es|Dominicanización fronteriza}}) and conducted the Parsley Massacre. In 1937, Trujillo, in an event known as the ''Masacre del Perejil'' ([[Parsley Massacre]]), ordered the Army to kill Haitians living on the border. The Army killed about 10,000 to 15,000 Haitians over six days, from the night of October 2, 1937, to October 8, 1937. To avoid leaving evidence of the Army's involvement, the soldiers used [[machete]]s instead of bullets. The soldiers of Trujillo interrogated anyone with dark skin, using the [[shibboleth]] "parsley" to differentiate Haitians from Afro-Dominicans when necessary, the "r" of parsley was difficult pronunciation for Haitians. As a result of the slaughter, the Dominican Republic agreed pay to Haiti the amount of $750,000, later reduced to $525,000. The genocide sought to be justified on the pretext of fearing infiltration, but was actually also a retaliation, commented on both in national currencies, as well as having been informed by the Military Intelligence Service (the dreaded SIM), the government Haitian cooperating with a plan that sought to overthrow Dominican exiles. In 2005 Dominican President [[Leonel Fernández]] criticized collective expulsions of Haitians were "improperly and inhumane." After a delegation from the [[United Nations]] issued a preliminary report stating that it found a profound problem of racism and discrimination against people of Haitian origin, the Dominican Foreign Minister, [[Carlos Morales Troncoso]], gave a formal statement saying "Our border with Haiti has its problems, this is our reality, and this must be understood. It's important not to confuse national sovereignty with indifference, and not to confuse security with [[xenophobia]]."{{cite news|author=Diógenes Pina|url=http://www.ipsnews.net/2007/10/dominican-republic-govrsquot-turns-deaf-ear-to-un-experts-on-racism/|title=Dominican Republic: Gov’t Turns Deaf Ear to UN Experts on Racism|publisher=IPS News Agency|date=31 October 2007|accessdate=13 January 2016}} After the [[2010 Haiti earthquake|earthquake]] that struck Haiti in 2010, the number of Haitians doubled to 2 million, most of them illegally crossed after the border opened for international aid. [[Human Rights Watch]] estimated in 70,000 Haitian immigrants legal and 1,930,000 illegal living in Dominican Republic. == Cultural contributions == African cultural remnants seen in the Dominican Republic in many different aspects, including music, dance, magic-religious beliefs, cuisine, economy, entertainment, motor habits, and language. === Music === [[File:Merengue dancing.jpg|thumb|right|Merengue dance.]] Perhaps the greatest influence of African slaves is observed in music and dance. Such influence comes from the dances, that, like the ''calenda'', practiced in the Dominican Republic, as elsewhere in America, from the early years of slavery. We must Father Labat, who toured the West Indies in the eighteenth century, a fairly thorough calenda. This dance derives, according to research by the folklorist [[Fradique Lizardo]], several Dominican popular rhythms. One of the most widespread is the Música de palos (Music of sticks), name that designates both the pace and the membranophones used. National Rhythms with obvious African imprint are sarandunga, Música de Gagá (Ganga's music, arrived from Haiti), Baile de Palos (dance of Sticks), Música de Congos (Music of Congos), Cantos de Hacha (Songs of axe),{{cite web|url=http://www.mindspring.com/~adiascar/musica/afro-dom.htm|title=Tradición Musical Afro-Dominicana|trans-title=Afro-Dominican Musical Tradition|language=es|first=Jose|last=Radhamés Veras|publisher=mindspring.com|accessdate=13 July 2017}} ''los congos'', ''la jaiba'' (the crab), el ''chenche matriculado'' (the chenche enrolled), etc. The ''salve'', which in the words of the U.S. ethnomusicologist [[Martha Ellen Davis (ethnomusicologist)|Martha Davis]], is the most typical of the traditional Dominican genres, has two styles: one distinctly Spanish, amétrico and antiphonal, and another polyrhythmic, strongly hybridized between the Spanish and African styles. Among African instruments are the ''los palos'' (the sticks), ''balsié'', and the ''gallumba''. It is important to also mark other musical instruments Dominicans of African origin such as the Palo mayor (mainmast), the canoita, los timbales (present in the [[bachata (music)|bachata]], also called bongos), and the tambora (Key instrument in the [[merengue music]], the Dominican national dance).[http://historiadominicana.com.do/cultura/folklore/369-la-discriminacion-de-la-cultura-africana-en-la-musica-dominicana.html Historia Dominicana. Conferencia: "La discriminación de la cultura africana en la música dominicana"] (Dominican History. "Discrimination of African culture in the Dominican music"). Wrote by Alejandro Paulino. General Archive of the Nation, 25 November 2010. For his part, the Bachata is a hybrid of the [[bolero]] (especially the bolero rhythm) of the Dominican Republic with other musical influences of African origin and other musical styles like the [[son (music)|son]], the merengue and the [[chachachá]].[http://www.buenastareas.com/ensayos/Origen-De-La-Bachata/4295004.html Buenas tareas] (Good tasks) On the other hand, there are also music genres Dominican widespread across the country, whose origin is uncertain, being considered of Spanish and African origin, depending of [[musicologists]] and historians. Such is the case of the merengue music. So, [[Luis Alberti]], one of the musicians considered as fathers of merengue, thinks that the roots of this music genre are purely Spanish. F. Lizardo, Dominican folklorist, by contrast, thinks that this origin is in the Bara tribe of [[Madagascar]], who came to the island in the eighteenth century and brought a dance called ''merengue'' that has spread throughout the Caribbean. A very similar pace, adds Lizardo, arrived today with the Yoruba of Dahomey. In the African polyrhythm was also the merengue. Also often linked to the origin of merengue a dance called URPA or UPA, a native of Havana and arrived in the Dominican Republic between 1838 and 1849. The dance sailed through the Caribbean coming to Puerto Rico where he was well received. One of the movements of this dance is called ''merengue'' which apparently is the way selected to call the dance, and came to the Dominican Republic where he evolved into the genre of merengue. However, the Cuban UPA is also a dance whose origin appears to be in [[West Africa]]. In fact, in early ls, despite its rise among the masses, the upper class did not accept the merengue for long, because apparently, their connection with African music. Another cause that weighed on the repudiation and attacks the merengue were literary texts that accompany it, usually risqué.[http://www.ciao.es/Merengue__Opinion_715565 Opinión sobre el merengue] (Opinion on the merengue). Retrieved 21 March 2013. Dominican folk music is intimately tied to religious culture, and interpreted primarily in the ''fiesta de santos'' (party of saints), also known, according to the area of the country, as ''velaciones'' (vigils), ''velas'' (candles) o ''noches de vela'' (sleepless nights). Other popular rhythms are of Spanish origin, such as the ''mangulina'' and the ''carabiné.'' Some of the most popular recording artists of these genres include [https://drjazzfestival.com/enerolisa-y-su-grupo-salve/ Enerolisa Nuñez] "The queen of Salve" and [https://g.co/kgs/GX6QJ6 Bembesito]. === Religion === Although most black Dominicans are [[Catholic Church|Roman Catholics]], magical-religious beliefs prevails among black Dominicans. Layers reflect African Christian syncretism operated since colonial times. The most characteristic feature is the [[Dominican Vudú]], which relates directly to the magical activity. Funeral rites contain many features of African descent that are shared with other American countries. A typical example is the ''baquiní'' o velorio del angelito. {{wide image|Afro-Dominicans in church.jpg|800px|Afro-Dominicans attending church service.}} === Institutions and cuisine === In the economic field include various institutions of mutual aid, existing both in the fields and in the cities. In rural areas, these institutions are in the form of groups of farmers who come together to collaborate on certain agricultural tasks such as planting, clearing of forests, land preparation, etc. Are called ''juntas'' (boards) o ''convites'' and have similar characteristics to Haitian combite closely related to the dokpwe of the [[Fon people]] of [[Dahomey]]. These tasks are accompanied by songs and musical instruments that serve as encouragement and coordination at work. All board members are required to reciprocate the assistance and collaboration in the work of others. After the day is a festival that is the responsibility of the landowner. Another institution of mutual aid, of African origin, is revolving credit system that goes by the name of St. corresponding to [[Susu (savings)|esusu]] and Yoruba. As in Nigeria and other parts of Afroamerica, the San is composed preferably female. It consists, as is well known, in the establishment of a common fund to which each participant's San, contributes with a sum monthly or weekly. Each partner receives, on a rotating basis, the total value of the box, starting with the organized. Some Dominican cuisine and dishes containing some products of African origin. Among the former are the guandul, the ñame and the funde. Typical African dishes seem to be the [[mangú]], prepared with green plantains and derivatives cocola kitchen, the fungí and the calalú. A common drink among the black slaves was the [[guarapo (drink)|guarapo]], made of [[sugar cane juice]] . === Buildings === African slaves were forced to build a cathedral that in time became the oldest in America. They built their monastery, first hospital and the [[Alcázar de Colón]]. In the 1540s, the Spanish authorities ordered the African slaves to build a wall to defend the city from attacks by pirates who ravaged the islands. They also built the ''Puerta de las Lamentaciones'' (Gate of wailing). == Racial discrimination and consciousness== That idea of black inferiority compared to the white was assumed by the whites because of their pro-slavery and, sometimes aggressive behavior with blacks, eventually would also be assumed by them, into believing, also, that their European culture was superior to the cultures from Africa and subjecting them to same (although many Afro-Dominican were able to maintain his cultures). Also, during the rule of Haiti (1822–44), the government of this country developed a black centrism, centrism that Dominicans refused. Moreover, Haitians made Dominicans feel as a distinct people racially, culturally and linguistically, while forbidding them to them use their customs. Dictator [[Rafael Leónidas Trujillo]], who ruled between 1930 and 1961, tenaciously promoted the anti-Haitian sentiment and used racial persecution and nationalistic fervor against Haitians. He is considered and blamed for creating the many racial categories that avoided the use of the word "black"{{cite web|url=https://www.diariolibre.com/noticias/afrodominicanos-pugnan-por-su-identidad-AKdl138844|title=Afrodominicanos pugnan por su identidad|trans-title=Afro-Dominicans fight for their identity|language=es|publisher=diariolibre.com|date=13 June 2007|accessdate=13 July 2017}} and, in 1955, he promotes an emigration from Spain to his country to "whiten" the population, increasing the white population over the black population, which he considered inferior.Hernández González, Manuel. La emigración canaria a América (Canary emigration to Americas). Page 27–31, 109–110. First Edition January, 2007 The practice continued under President [[Joaquín Balaguer]], who often complained that Haitian immigration in the Dominican Republic was ''blackening'' the country. In 1990, he was blamed for blocking the presidential aspirations of leading black candidate [[José Francisco Peña Gómez]], spreading rumors that he was actually Haitian.{{cite news|last=Franco|first=Franklin|authorlink=Franklin Franco|url=http://hoy.com.do/pena-gomez-balaguer-y-el-racismo-iii/|title=Peña Gómez, Balaguer y el racismo (III)|trans-title=Peña Gómez, Balaguer and racism (III)|language=es|newspaper=Hoy.com.do|date=2 September 2005|accessdate=13 July 2017}} An envoy of the [[UN]] in October 2007 found that there was racism against blacks in general, and particularly against Haitians, which proliferate in every segment of Dominican society. According to a study conducted by the Dominican Studies Institute [[CUNY]], about 80% of the contemporary Dominican population has ancestry from West and Central Africa in different degrees.{{cite journal|last=Torres-Saillant|first=Silvio|title=The Tribulations of Blackness: Stages in Dominican Racial Identity|journal=Latin American Perspectives|date=May 1998|jstor=2634170|subscription=yes|volume=25|issue=3|pages=126–146}} A variety of terms are used to represent a range of skin tones, such as ''moreno'', ''canelo'', ''Indian'', ''indiesito'', ''blanquito'', and ''rubio''. Ramona Hernández, director of the Dominican Studies Institute at [[City College of New York]] asserts that the terms were originally a defense against [[racism]]: "During the Trujillo regime, people who had dark skin were rejected, so they created their own mechanism to fight against the rejection". == Notable people == * [[Ivan Barias]] * [[Robinson Canó]] * [[Vladimir Guerrero]] * [[Joan Guzman]] * [[Ulises Heureaux]] * [[Al Horford]] * [[Adrián Beltré]] * [[Pedro Martínez]] * [[David Ortiz]] * [[Rubby Perez]] * [[Dascha Polanco]] * [[José Joaquín Puello]] * [[Judy Reyes]] * [[Fernando Rodney]] * [[Zoe Saldana]] * [[Alfonso Soriano]] * [[Arlenis Sosa]] * [[Sammy Sosa]] * [[Oscar Taveras]] * [[Annerys Vargas]] * [[Johnny Ventura]] * [[Antony Santos]] *[https://g.co/kgs/GX6QJ6 Bembesito] ==See also== {{Portal|Dominican Republic}} * [[Cocolo|Cocolos]] * [[Samaná Americans]] * [[Afro-Latin Americans]] * [[Black Hispanic and Latino Americans]] * [[Emancipados]] ==Notes== {{Reflist|group=nb}} ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20160306211954/http://www.lameca.org/dossiers/palos_drumming/eng/index.htm Article on Dominican Palos music written by Dr Martha Ellen Davis at lameca.org] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20150112044424/http://www.gnuasd.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=342%3Aies-racista-el-pueblo-dominicano&catid=53%3Anoticias-filosofia&Itemid=54 ¿Es racista el pueblo dominicano?] (Are the Dominican people racist?) {{Dominican Republic topics}} {{Ancestry and ethnicity in Dominican Republic}} {{African diaspora}} [[Category:Afro-Dominican (Dominican Republic)| ]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in the Dominican Republic]] [[Category:People of African descent|Dominican Republic]] [[Category:Dominican Republic people of African descent| ]]

'''Mir Nasir Khan Talpur''' was the last [[Amir]] of the land that included [[Sind province|Sindh]] and parts of present-day [[Balochistan]] and was one of the most active administrators after the decline of the [[Mughal Empire]]. He made [[Hyderabad, Sindh|Hyderabad]] the capital of his empire and constructed two forts in the city known as the Pakka Qilla (Brick Fort) and the Kacha Qilla (Mud Fort) and he also built the Maula Ali Qadam Gah (The footsteps of Ali(A.S)), a Shia shrine at the center of the city. He was a strong follower of the [[Sufi]] tradition. He donated a lot of his personal wealth to the Tomb of [[Shah Abdul Latif Bhittai]] at [[Bhit|Bhit Shah]]. He and his 30,000 forces were defeated by the forces of the [[British Empire]] led by [[Charles James Napier|Charles Napier]] at the [[Battle of Miani]].
Mir Nasir Khan Talpur's defeat was an ill omen for the last [[Mughal Emperor]] [[Bahadur Shah Zafar]].
