{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2013}} {{Use British English|date=February 2013}} The '''Groom Porter''' was an office at the royal court of the [[List of British monarchs|monarch of Britain]], who had "the Inspection of the King's Lodgings, and takes care that they are provided with Tables, Chairs, Firing, &c. As also to provide Cards, Dice, &c. when there is playing at Court: To decide Disputes which arise in Gaming". He was also responsible for 'oversight of common Billiards Tables, common Bowling Grounds, Dicing Houses, Gaming Houses and Common tennis Courts and power of Licensing the same within the Citys of London and Westminster or Borough of Southwark.<ref name="offhold">'Hunting, sporting and gaming: Groom Porters and Masters of the Tennis Courts', ''Office-Holders in Modern Britain: Volume 11 (revised): Court Officers, 1660-1837'' (2006), pp. 224-225. [http://www.british-history.ac.uk/report.aspx?compid=43819&strquery=groom porter]. Date accessed: 7 November 2008.</ref>
The title may originally have referred to the keeper of the king's furnishings in his bedchamber. It was a position in the royal household, and therefore had certain privileges associated with it.<ref>[http://www.thefreedictionary.com/Groom+porter Thefreedictionary.com: Definition of Groom porter]</ref> In 1702 the remuneration was raised to £680 per year, which it remained until it was abolished with other sinecure offices at court in 1782.<ref name="offhold"/> Eventually, the term became used for the owner, or operator of a gaming hall.<ref>[http://www.historicgames.com/vbook/book.html Aske the "Groom Porter"]</ref>
==List of Groom Porters==
===Before 1660=== {{Expand list|date=August 2008}} * ?c.1547-1556 [[Edward Lewknor (died 1556)|Edward Lewknor]], Esquire (to King [[Edward VI of England|Edward VI]] and Queen [[Mary I of England|Mary]]).<ref>J.G. Nichols (ed.), ''The Diary of Henry Machyn'', Camden Society Old Series XLII (London 1848), [https://archive.org/stream/diaryofhenrymach00machrich#page/108/mode/2up pp. 108, 114.] Machyn calls him 'master Lecknolle'.</ref> * 1563 [[Nicholas Fortescue the Elder|Nicholas Fortescue]], esqr.<ref>Visitacon [Visitation] of the County of Warwick Taken 1619 by Samson Lennard, Augustine Vincent</ref>
===1660-1782=== *1660–1665: Sir Richard Hubbert *1665–1678: Thomas Offley *1678–1699: [[Thomas Neale]] *1700–1705: William Rowley *1705–1743: [[Thomas Archer]] *1743–1763: [[Charles FitzRoy-Scudamore|Charles FitzRoy]] (FitzRoy-Scudamore from 1749) *1763–1764: [[Francis Buller (MP)|Francis Buller]] *1764–1765: [[Robert Wood (engraver)|Robert Wood]] *1765–1782: [[George Paulet, 12th Marquess of Winchester|George Paulet]]<ref name="offhold"/>

{{orphan|date= December 2012}}
The '''Hero thrill show''' fundraising event helps ensure that the children of [[Philadelphia]] Police Officers and Firefighters that are killed or severely disabled in the line of duty can receive financial assistance in order to complete their education.
==History== Created in 1954 because of an explosion that took the lives of ten firefighters, the Police and Firefighter Thrill Show has assisted over 800 students graduate from various colleges and universities. With the help of these scholarships, there are currently 50 students attending colleges throughout the United States.
The main source of funding is through the sale of tickets and proceeds coming from the annual Hero Thrill Show, which is held in the [[Wachovia Spectrum Complex]]. Throughout the year, the Hero Thrill Show, which is typically held the second weekend in September has included major contributions from local celebrities, sport figures, and police and firefighters.
On January 20, 2006 the President of the Hero Scholarship Fund announced that "After carefully comparing revenues over the past several years, including decreases as well as the expense and difficulty in putting on the show, it has been decided to discontinue the show...." * In April, 2006, James J. Binns, a Philadelphia Lawyer, founded the Hero Thrill Show Inc., which assumed production of the Hero Thrill Show and the administration of funds generated by the Hero Thrill Show. The Board of Directors is chaired by Mr. Binns and is composed of the Police Commissioner, Fire Commissioner, President of the Fraternal Order of Police, Lodge Number 5, President of the International Association of Firefighters, Local 22 and a number of Philadelphia Business Leaders.
The first show which featured a 15-hour [[rodeo]], raised $78,000 with western movie stars [[Gene Autry]], [[Roy Rogers]], [[Dale Evans]], and [[Tex Ritter]] attending. For decades the Thrill Show was performed at JFK Stadium (originally Municipal Stadium). When this Philadelphia landmark was torn down, the show moved first to the Civic Center, and then to the Convention Center. It has returned to its old home and is now performed on the grounds of the stadium complex on Broad Street in South Philadelphia. The past few years has shown a dramatic growth with the event blooming into a vast family affair with tens of thousand of fans enjoying a carnival, car show, concert, and fire works show. In 2006, the event raised $360,000 in scholarship money.
2011, is the 6th anniversary of the Hero Thrill Show under the leadership of the Hero Thrill Show, Inc. The performers and exhibitors are all active Police Officers and Firefighters who continue the tradition that was started in 1954 by risking their lives performing daredevil demonstrations utilizing equipment that is standard issue in the departments.
==Recent attendance== In 2006, under the leadership of the Hero Thrill Show, Inc., attendance jumped to over 13,000 spectators. Attendance has steadily increased over the past 5 years. 2010 was another banner year with crowds in excess of 50,000 in attendance. Funds generated are being used to defray the cost of college education for the children of police and firefighters that have been killed while on duty.
===2012 Thrill Show=== The 2012 Grand Marshal was [[A. Thomas Schomberg]], the world-renowned sculptor of the "ROCKY" statue that is situated at the steps of the [[Philadelphia Museum of Art]]. Philadelphia's own Bob Pantano, who hosts the first and longest running radio dance party in the nation on 98.1 [[WOGL]], entertained the crowd with music for the five-hour fundraiser.
The families of police officers Brian Lorenzo, Bradley Fox and Moses Walker and firefighters Daniel Sweeney and Robert Neary will benefit from the 2012 fundraiser.
===2011 Thrill Show=== The 2011 Grand Marshal was '''Gerald Tommaso DeLouise''' better known by his stage name '''[[Burt Young]]'''. An American actor, painter and author, he is best known for his [[Academy Award]]-nominated role as [[Sylvester Stallone]]'s brother-in-law and best friend Paulie in the ''[[Rocky (film series)|Rocky]]'' film series. Philadelphia's own Bob Pantano, who hosts the first and longest running radio dance party in the nation on 98.1, entertained the crowd with music for the five-hour fundraiser.
The 2011 Hero thrill show brought back the Highway Patrol Motorcycle Drill Team, the elite K-9 Unit, the Strike Force Bicycle Stunt Team and the Philadelphia Police & Fire Pipes and Drums. Philly’s famous sports team mascots The [[Phillie Phanatic]], [[Swoop (Philadelphia Eagles)|Swoop]] and [[Hip Hop (mascot)|Hip Hop]] as well as the Sixers Dancers and [[Philadelphia Eagles Cheerleaders|Eagles Cheerleaders]] made special appearances. Guests were to be able to participate or watch the action-packed [[Sonny Hill]] basketball shootout competition as well.

'''Joseph Forer''' (1910–1986 {{cite web | title = Forer and Rein (Washington, D.C.) | publisher = WorldCat OCLC Identities | url = http://www.worldcat.org/identities/lccn-n2004071849/ | date = 2010 | accessdate = 20 March 2017}}) was a 20th-Century American attorney who, with partner [[David Rein]], supported [[Progressive Era|Progressive]] causes including discriminated communists and African-Americans. They were members of the [[National Lawyers Guild]] and its DC chapter. Forer was an expert in the "Lost Laws" of Washington, DC, enacted in 1872–1873, that outlawed segregation at business places. {{cite news | title = Metro Scene | publisher = Washington Post | url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/local/1986/06/25/metro-scene/820fd870-a989-4db3-b2dd-a504cce6cf1e/ | date = 26 June 1986 | accessdate = 20 March 2017}} ==Background== Forer received his BA from [[Rutgers University]] and law degree from the [[University of Pennsylvania]]. {{cite book | first = Joan | last = Quigley | title = Just Another Southern Town: Mary Church Terrell's Fight for Racial Justice in the Nation's Capital | publisher = Oxford University Press | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=BP7VCgAAQBAJ | pages = 4 (Terrell), 13 (location), 19, 144 (schooling, career), 155, 164, 227 | date = 2016 | accessdate = 20 March 2017}} ==Career== ===New Deal=== [[File:1099 14th Street – National Labor Relations Board - sign.JPG|thumb|right|Plaque outside [[1099 14th Street]] NW in Washington, D.C., the [[National Labor Relations Board|NLRB]] HW (2013), whete Forer worked in the 1930s]] In the 1930s, like his friend David Rein, Forer worked for the [[National Labor Relations Board]] and the [[Office of Price Administration]] during the [[New Deal]]. ===1940s: NLG vs. HUAC=== In 1946, David Rein joined Joseph Forer as private practice law partners in Washington, DC. Together, they "represented more than 100 persons who had been termed 'unfriendly' witnesses by the [[House Committee on Un-American Activities]], the [[Senate Internal Security Subcommittee]] of the Senate subcommittee headed by the late senator [[Joseph McCarthy]]." {{cite news | title = David Rein, Civil Rights Lawyer, Dies | publisher = Washington Post | url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/local/1979/08/15/david-rein-civil-rights-lawyer-dies/e48bd72a-0bee-4b08-84b1-eccf98aed97e/ | date = 15 August 1975 | accessdate = 20 March 2017}} As historian Joan Quigley describes:
In the late 1940s, while Congress and the executive branch trawled for evidence of disloyalty and subversion, Rein and Forer immersed themselves in difficult and disfavored causes: opposing the [[Mundt-Nixon Bill]]; defending labor unions and alleged Communists; upholding the Bill of Rights. Rein ... represented [[Gerhard Eisler]] ... As progressives and New Deal veterans, Forer and Rein also nurtured ties to the [[National Lawyers Guild]], which [[HUAC]] had branded a Communist front in 1944.
Forer was chairman of the District Affairs Committee of the DC chapter of the National Lawyers Guild. {{cite book | first = Marvin | last = Caplan | title = Farther Along: A Civil Rights Memoir | publisher = LSU Press | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=G25fxCJFheYC | page = 113 (chairman), 114 (afternoon), 115 (NLG opinion), 116 (next door), 122 (Trenton Terrace), 131 (HUAC), 140 (Terrell's tray) | date = 1999 | accessdate = 20 March 2017}} Historian Maarten Zwiers wrote:
Joe Forer ... was senior partner in Forer and Rein, the Communist Party's leading law firm in the capital. He had defended people accused of communist sympathies before [[James Eastland|Eastland]]'s [[United States Senate Subcommittee on Internal Security|Internal Security Subcommittee]] on several occasions ... {{cite book | first = Maarten | last = Zwiers | title = Senator James Eastland: Mississippi's Jim Crow Democrat | publisher = LSU Press | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=YjLeCQAAQBAJ | page = 1 | date = 2015 | accessdate = 20 March 2017}}
He also refers to him as "the Communist Party's lawyer." Historian Marvin Caplan wrote:
When a staff attorney at a [[HUAC]] hearing asked Joe Forer how many times he had appeared before the committee, Forer couldn't remember. Too many times, he said, to be able to give an exact figure.
Attorney [[Victor Rabinowitz]] recalled in his memoir that Forer's circle of communist-supportive lawyers stretched to New York City (headquarters of the National Lawyers Guild). They included [[Harry Sacher]], [[Abraham Unger|Abe Unger]], David Freeman, David Rein, and Rabinowitz himself, "all lawyers active in the representation of witnesses before congressional committees." He explained:
Unger and Freeman were attorneys for the (Communist) Party; Sacher had been lead defense in the prosecution of Communist party leaders under the Smith Act; I was a member of the Party and the others were close to it if not members. We certainly weren't making Party policy, but our views would have some influence on the Party and its members. {{cite book | first = Victor | last = Rabinowitz | title = Unrepentant Leftist: A Lawyer's Memoir | publisher = University of Illinois Press | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=iMaVigHoraAC | page = 122 | date = 1996 | accessdate = 20 March 2017}}
In 1948, [[Lee Pressman]] joined Forer in representing [[Gerhard Eisler]] and four others (Irving Potash, vice president of the [[International Fur & Leather Workers Union|Fur and Leather Workers Union]]; [[Ferdinand Smith|Ferdinand C. Smith]], secretary of the [[National Maritime Union]]; Charles A. Doyle of the [[Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers International Union|Gas, Coke and Chemical Workers Union]], and John Williamson, labor secretary of the [[CPUSA]]). On May 5, 1946, Pressman and Forer received a preliminary injunction so their defendants might have hearings with examiners unconnected with the investigations and prosecutions by examiners of the [[Immigration and Naturalization Service]]. {{cite news | title = Eisler, 4 Others Win New Hearings: Goldsborough Enjoins Their Deportation Pending Compliance With 1946 Law | publisher = New York Times | url= https://www.nytimes.com/1948/05/06/archives/eisler-4-others-win-new-hearings-goldsborough-enjoins-their.html | pages = 18 | date = 6 May 1948 | accessdate = 18 March 2017}} ===1950s: McCarthyism=== [[File:Einstein-cartoon1.jpg|thumb|right|Cartoon of [[Albert Einstein]], shed of "Pacifism" wings, standing near pillar of "World Peace," rolling up sleeves and holding sword of "Preparedness" (by [[Charles R. Macauley]], circa 1933)]] From 1951 to 1953, Forer, with [[John Abt]] and [[Vito Marcantonio]], represented the [[CPUSA]] in the matter of ''[[Herbert Brownell, Jr.]], Attorney General of the United States, Petitioner v. the [[Communist Party of the United States of America]], Respondent''. {{cite web | title = Subversive Activities Control Board: Herbert Brownell, Jr., Attorney General of the United States, Petitioner v. the Communist Party of the United States of America, Respondent: Report of the Board | publisher = U.S. Government Printing Office | url = https://archive.org/stream/herbertbrownellj1956unit#page/n7/mode/2up/search/forer | place = Washington, DC | page = 1 | date = 1953 | accessdate = 21 March 2017}} {{cite web | title = Home | publisher = I Vote My Conscience: The Debates, Speeches, and Writings of Vito Marcantonio | url = http://www.vitomarcantonio.org/ | date = | accessdate = 24 March 2017}} {{cite book | first = Vito | last = Marcantonio | title = I Vote My Conscience | publisher = Vito Marcantonio Memorial | url = http://www.vitomarcantonio.com/oa_politician_social_worker_lawyer.html | pages = 477–482 | date = 1956 | accessdate = 24 March 2017}} {{cite book | first = Vito | last = Marcantonio | editor = Annette T. Rubenstein | title = I Vote My Conscience | publisher = VitoMarcantonio.com | url = http://vitomarcantonio.com/vm_a%20new%20intro%20--%20Annette%20T%20Rubinstein.html | pages = | date = 1956 | accessdate = 24 March 2017}} On April 8, 1953, Forer represented [[Howard Selsam]] of the [[Jefferson School of Social Science]].{{cite book |last=Selsam |first=Howard |year=1953 |title=Testimony of Howard Selsam before the United States Senate Committee on the Judiciary, Subcommittee To Investigate the Administration of the Internal Security Act and Other Internal Security Laws. [Hearings on] Subversive Influence in the Educational Process. Part 7 : hearings before the United States Senate Committee on the Judiciary, Subcommittee To Investigate the Administration of the Internal Security Act and Other Internal Security Laws, Eighty-Third Congress, first session, on Apr. 7, 8, 1953. |url=http://academic.brooklyn.cuny.edu/english/melani/bc/senate_1952/selsam.html |location=Washington, DC |publisher=U.S. Government Printing Office. |accessdate=7 May 2014}} On April 24, 1953, Forer represented [[William Frauenglass]], an English teacher at the [[James Madison High School (Brooklyn)|James Madison High School]] in Brooklyn, New York, before the [[United States Senate Subcommittee on Internal Security]]. {{cite book | title = Subversive Influence in the Educational Process | publisher = US GPO | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=3cIHAAAAMAAJ | pages = 838–841 | date = 1952 | accessdate = 3 September 2018}} Reading of the testimony, world-famous scientist [[Albert Einstein]] wrote Frauenglass a letter, {{cite web | title = | publisher = Einstein Virtuell | url = http://einstein-virtuell.mpiwg-berlin.mpg.de/VEA/SC516287227_MOD-1744214250_SEQ1202484_SL861364620_en.html | date = | accessdate = 3 September 2018}} which reached the ''[[New York Times]]'' (Einstein had added a postscript stating the letter "need not remain confidential"), advising "every intellectual called before a Congressional investigating committee should refuse to testify, and 'must be prepared for jail and economic ruin, in short, for the sacrifice of his personal welfare in the interest of the cultural welfare of his country'." {{cite news | first = Leonard | last = Buder | title = Refuse to Testify,' Einstein Advises Intellectuals Called In by Congress | publisher = New York Times | url = https://www.nytimes.com/1953/06/12/archives/-refuse-to-testify-eins | date = 12 June 1953 | accessdate = 3 September 2018}} Frauenglass did refuse to testify further – and he did lose his job. {{cite web | title = Einstein, Plumbers, and McCarthyism | publisher = Institute for Advanced Study | url = https://www.ias.edu/ideas/2017/einstein-mccarthyism | date = 2017 | accessdate = 3 September 2018}} (See "[[Political views of Albert Einstein]]") In 1958, Forer represented [[Clara Hutcherson Saba]] before HUAC. {{cite web | title = Communist Activities in the South | publisher = U.S. Government Printing Office | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=s9UJAAAAIAAJ | page = 2648 | date = July 1958 | accessdate = 20 March 2017}} ===Lost Laws and ''DC v. John R. Thompson Co.''=== ====Mary Church Terrell==== [[File:Mary Church Terrell - NARA - 559207.tif|thumb|right|150px|Painting of [[Mary Church Terrell]] by [[Betsy Graves Reyneau]], 1888–1964]] In May 1949, Dr. [[Mary Church Terrell]] decided to take on the issue of desegregation head-on. She consulted Forer. Forer led the [[National Lawyer Guild]]'s DC chapter in submitting an opinion in their favor. With such advice, Dr. Terrell and colleagues [[Clark F. King]], [[Essie Thompson]], and [[Arthur F. Elmer]] entered the segregated Thompson's Restaurant, next door to the offices of Forer and Rein's office on 14th Street, NW, in Washington, DC, between H Street and New York Avenue and across the street from the [[Trans-Lux Theatre]]. When refused service, Terrell & Co. sued. Attorney Ringgold Hart, representing Thompson, argued on April 1, 1950, that District laws were unconstitutional. Regardless, Forer's research found that the [[U.S. Congress]] had jurisdiction over DC and so could overrule segregation; [[Charles H. Houston]], dean of [[Howard University]] Law School concurred. ====District of Columbia v. John R. Thompson Co.==== [[File:Oblique facade 2, US Supreme Court.jpg|thumb|right|[[Supreme Court of the United States]].]] The case ''[[District of Columbia v. John R. Thompson Co.]]'' reached the [[U.S. Supreme Court]]. Forer and Rein argued the case. On June 8, 1953, the court ruled that segregated eating places in Washington, DC, were unconstitutional. The ''Washington Post'' recounted in 1985, "Four days after the Supreme Court ruled, Mary Terrell and the three other original complainants went back to Thompson's. Joe Forer followed them in. As he recalls the moment, the manager, himself, came over and personally, even obsequiously, carried Mary Terrell's tray to the table." {{cite news | title = City Voices | publisher = Washington Post | url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/local/1985/04/25/city-voices/93621dd6-dd69-4ba5-a212-3508a06d8219/ | date = 25 April 1985 | accessdate = 20 March 2017}} {{cite news | first = Carl | last = Bernstein | title = The Washington I Once Knew | publisher = Daily Beast | url = http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2009/01/20/the-washington-i-once-knew.html | date = 20 January 2009 | accessdate = 20 March 2017}} ===Other cases=== Forer and Rein served the rights of striking workers, foreign-born aliens (with leftist leanings, e.g., [[Gerhard Eisler]]), and servicemen. They won for the [[National Council for American-Soviet Friendship]] the right to contest in court its designation by the attorney general as a "subversive organization." They also represented members of the press on strike against the ''Washington Post'' in 1975. In 1960–1961, Forer and [[John Abt]] represented the [[CPUSA]] in ''Communist Party of the United States vs. Subversive Activities Control Board, 367 U.S. 1 (1961).'' {{cite web | title = Communist Party of the United States vs. Subversive Activities Control Board, 367 U.S. 1 (1961) | publisher = The Fire | url = https://www.thefire.org/first-amendment-library/litigator/joseph-forer/ | date = 25 August 1977 | accessdate = 20 March 2017}} ===FBI target=== In 1977, a release of internal memos of the [[FBI]] revealed, according to the ''Washington Post'', that:
An Oct. 4, 1951 memo to Hoover said that a search of trash at the Washington offices of [[National Lawyers Guild|guild]] lawyers Joseph Forer and David Rein had uncovered a draft resolution urging President [[Harry S. Truman|Truman]] to authorize a citizens' investigation of the FBI because of its alleged excesses in loyalty checks. {{cite news | first = Susanna | last = McBee | title = FBI Sifted Trash, Tapped Phones of Lawyers Guild | publisher = Washington Post | url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/politics/1977/08/25/fbi-sifted-trash-tapped-phones-of-lawyers-guild/6daee822-6e89-4c55-adcf-8c7da1ec4768/ | date = 25 August 1977 | accessdate = 20 March 2017}}
===Retirement=== Forer retired from practice with Rein in July 1978. ==Personal and death== Forer's daughter, [[Jane F. Gentleman]], is a notable statistician.{{citation|url=http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/washingtonpost/obituary.aspx?n=florence-forer&pid=3346353|title=Florence Forer|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|date=March 29, 2005|department=Paid death notices|accessdate=2017-11-27}}{{citation|url=http://www.soph.uab.edu/awards/norwoodaward/firstaward|title=First Annual Janet L. Norwood Award|publisher=University of Alabama School of Public Health|accessdate=2017-11-27}} He was the uncle of author Richard Forer. {{cite web | title = Bio | publisher = RichardForer.com | url = http://www.richardforer.com/about-rich/bio/ | date = | accessdate = 20 March 2017}} Forer, Rein, and many friends and associates lived at Trenton Terrace, 950 Mississippi Avenue SE, Washington DC 20032. As a child, [[Carl Bernstein]] knew Joseph Forer and David Rein. ==See also== * [[Mary Church Terrell]] * [[Charles H. Houston]] * [[Mundt-Nixon Bill]] * [[Gerhard Eisler]] * [[HUAC]] * [[National Lawyers Guild]] * [[Lee Pressman]] * [[John Abt]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External sources== * {{cite web | title = Forer and Rein (Washington, D.C.) | publisher = WorldCat OCLC Identities | url = http://www.worldcat.org/identities/lccn-n2004071849/ | date = 2010 | accessdate = 20 March 2017}} * [http://www.vitomarcantonio.org/images.php VitoAntonio.com]: Image of Joseph Forer with John Abt and Vito Marcantonio {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Pressman, Lee}} [[Category:1910 births]] [[Category:1986 deaths]] [[Category:Espionage in the United States]] [[Category:Members of the Communist Party USA]] [[Category:Rutgers University alumni]] [[Category:University of Pennsylvania Law School alumni]] [[Category:Lawyers who have represented the United States government]] [[Category:American civil servants]] [[Category:American activists]] [[Category:American communists]]

{{multiple issues| {{refimprove|date=September 2013}} {{essay|date=September 2013}} }} [[Lifestyle (sociology)|Lifestyle]] changes have been increasing slowly since the introduction of [[media (communication)|media]]. Media – [[film]]s, [[television show]]s, [[magazine]]s, and more recently, the [[Internet]] (i.e. [[Blogs|self-written blogs]] and popular [[website]]s) are the main sources of lifestyle influence around the world. Lifestyle changes include how people eat, dress, and communicate. [[Celebrity endorsements]] are prevalent. Lifestyle trends have always been influenced by the [[wealth]]y and [[celebrity|famous]], whether they are spotted at leisure or in a paid advertisement. At the dawn of the media age, the newspaper, popular magazines like ''[[Life (magazine)|Life]]'', and TV allowed the general public glimpse lifestyles that before were only available to the imagination. After its creation, the Internet became arguably the most powerful medium for spotting and influencing trends, not just by celebrities but by the average person. The computer era has changed the way people obtain their news, perspectives and communication. Magazines are still popular, but advertisers now often supply a [[web address]] where consumers can visit for more information than a print ad can provide. The average American household has two personal computers, making the Internet easily accessible. The rise of [[user-generated content]] is exemplified by the fact that anyone with Internet access can create a blog or an [[online journal]], whether personal or commercial, which might detail someone's experience in a new restaurant, a purchased item of clothing or knickknack, or a review to a film. With the advent of the Android phone and its relative ease of uploading photos to social media sites such as Facebook, one can get an idea of how quickly an idea, pub review, or coveted object can be shared. Advertisers have always been privy to the strength of [[word-of-mouth]] and have tapped into [[social media]], including [[Facebook]], [[Twitter]], and [[Tumblr]] to make their wares known. [[Douglas Kellner]] writes, "Radio, television, film, and the other products of media culture provide materials out of which we forge our very identities; our sense of selfhood; our notion of what it means to be male or female; our sense of class, of ethnicity and race, of nationality, of sexuality; and of "us" and "them.""<ref name=Kellner>{{cite web|last=Kellner|first=Douglas|title=CULTURAL STUDIES, MULTICULTURALISM, AND MEDIA CULTURE|url=http://pages.gseis.ucla.edu/faculty/kellner/papers/SAGEcs.htm|accessdate=13 April 2012}}</ref>
==Celebrity-endorsed beauty and health products== Media affects how people diet. Commercials advertise special [[diet pill|pill]]s, [[Juice fasting|juice fasts]], [[raw diet]]s, and all-soy diets. Celebrities [[Celebrity endorsement|endorse]] food products and diets that promise dramatic results in little time. Audiences are impressionable depending on their age range. [[Salma Hayek]], who has been using juice cleanses for 15 years promises health with her own line, Cooler Cleanse. [[Jennifer Aniston]] is famous for her [[yoga]]-body and has revealed her secret, which the public has taken as a big health influence. So Feminine provides health and lifestyle advice taken from celebrities and their personal assistants/trainers. Reality star [[Kim Kardashian]] endorsed QuickTrim, a [[Weight loss drug|weight-loss product]] designed to get rid of unwanted weight. Recent news articles claim that the product is unhealthy, and Kardashian is facing a lawsuit for her endorsement. Along with cleanses are celebrity [[beauty products]]. Salma Hayek has a [[CVS Pharmacy|CVS]]-exclusive line of hair care and cosmetic products, called Nuance. Admirers of Hayek who covet her beauty have hope that her products will make them look appealing. Websites such as ''[[Cosmopolitan (magazine)|Cosmopolitan]]'' and Celebrity Beauty Buzz list favorite skincare and makeup products of celebrities so readers can purchase the same products in hopes of achieving similar results. Health articles note that the meticulous science process is often forgotten in favor of the newer-is-better trend taking over mass media. Harvard School of Public Health states, "With [media reports'] emphasis on short, "newsworthy" pieces, the media often only report the results of single studies, and many stories are chosen simply because the results run contrary to current health recommendations."<ref>{{cite web|last=Harvard School of Public Health|title=The Nutrition Source: Deciphering Media Stories on Diet|url=http://www.hsph.harvard.edu/nutritionsource/nutrition-news/media/|publisher=Harvard School of Public Health|accessdate=13 April 2012}}</ref> Popular magazines and websites often focus on what's new in the world of celebrity health and beauty routines and forgo substantial research in order to bring to the masses what the public are truly interested in; quick, easy-way-out health fixes such as these juice cleanses and detox diets.
Celebrity endorsements are effective due to their high profile presence in the media. Their [[physical attractiveness]] is central to their ability to sell products to an impressionable audience. Celebrities are also effective because they are what many people aspire to be or look like. Celebrities act as symbols of personal desire. "In an attempt to communicate the merits of their product or brand," says Michael A. Kamins, Ph.D., New York University, "advertisers have often chosen to use endorsement as a promotional strategy." Additionally, "the use of celebrity spokespeople has always been a favorite strategy among agencies."<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kamins|first=Michael, A.|title=An Investigation into the "Match-Up" Hypothesis in Celebrity Advertising: When Beauty May be Only Skin Deep|journal=Journal of Advertising|volume=19|issue=1|pages=4–13|year=1990|jstor=10.2307/4188750}}</ref> Kamins informs that advertisers are well aware of how easily celebrities influence consumer habits; it is the combination of their physical appeal and their high status that draws in the public. He explains, "Indeed, a considerable amount of research exists both in the social sciences and in marketing supporting a strategy by showing that a physically attractive source facilitates attitude change toward issues, products, and ad-based evaluations."
Research suggests that there is a link between the product itself and the image of the celebrity. The celebrity, in this case, indeed acts as a symbol of the product. The physical attractiveness of the celebrity endorser improves the appearance of the product, or rather, the advertisement. In simpler terms, it makes a bigger impact on the audience if "the characteristics of the product 'match-up' with the image conveyed by the celebrity," as suggested by Kamins' research. He continues, "This 'match-up' hypothesis suggests that the visual imagery contained in the ad conveys information over and above that contained in explicit verbal arguments." A journal notes that the match up hypothesis "specifies that perceivers distinguish multiple types of good looks, and that in advertising, certain beauty ideals are more appropriately paired with specific products than with others."<ref>{{cite journal|last=Solomon|first=Michael, R. |author2=Richard D. Ashmore |author3=Laura C. Longo|title=The Beauty Match-up Hypothesis: Congruence between Types of Beauty and Product Images in Advertising|journal=Journal of Advertising|date=December 1992|volume=XXI|issue=4|pages=23–24|jstor=10.2307/4188855|doi=10.1080/00913367.1992.10673383}}</ref> Another journal further explains, "In the match-up hypothesis, the message conveyed by the image of the celebrity and the message about the product ought to converge in effective advertisements."<ref>{{cite journal|last=Kahle|first=Lynn R.|author2=Pamela M. Homer |title=Physical Attractiveness of the Celebrity Endorser: A Social Adaptation Perspective|journal=Journal of Consumer Research |date=March 1985|volume=11|issue=4|pages=954–961|jstor=2489220|doi=10.1086/209029}}</ref>
However, research also notes that physical attractiveness is the key detail when analyzing [[consumer behavior]]. If a celebrity is less than attractive according to society's standards, the advertising campaign may potentially be less effective. Still, advertisements starring celebrities are generally effective due to their popularity and presence in media.
There are times when physical attractiveness of the celebrity is not relevant, and that is when the product showcased in the advertisement does not claim to enhance the consumer's appearance. Under this circumstance, the "match-up" hypothesis does not apply because the product is not particularly attractive. Attractive products include luxurious sports cars, designer clothing, anti-aging products, beauty products (i.e. foundation that smooths fine lines, blemishes, pigmentation, and promises a flawless canvas onto which the rest of a woman's makeup may be applied), hair care (i.e. shampoos, conditioners, and shine-enhancing serums that boast rare ingredients and professional results), modern-day technology products such as everything Apple produces (iPhone, Mac computers) and the brands that strive to mimic these products' sleek appearances, etc. "Unattractive" products include toilet paper, household cleaning items, groceries and food, personal hygiene products, music, movies, etc. Though, it can be debated that music and movies do not depend on the attractiveness of its performers; attractiveness vs. talent in the respected fields depends on many factors regarding the consumers, such as age and gender.
B. Zafer Erdogan says, "Because of their fame, celebrities serve not only to create and maintain attention, but also to achieve high recall rates for marcoms messages (marketing communication) in today's highly cluttered environments."<ref>{{cite journal|last=Erdogan|first=B. Zafer|title=Celebrity Endorsement: A Literature Review|journal=Journal of Marketing Management|year=1999|volume=15|issue=4|pages=291–314|doi=10.1362/026725799784870379|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1362/026725799784870379#preview|accessdate=22 April 2012}}</ref> This serves as proof that advertising agencies use celebrities to cut through the clutter that is [[mass media]]. Having celebrities in their advertising campaigns helps them promote their products in the sense that notable figures are what gets the attention of the public, rather than the product itself.
==The beauty ideal and plastic surgery== Among the many [[beauty product|beauty]] and health products advertised and media showcasing celebrity beauty as the most desired beauty, is the frustration that comes with consumers using these products and not achieving the results they want. In a psychological study which aimed to examine the correlation of the acceptance of cosmetic surgery and prevalence of celebrity influence, researchers found that there was an extremely significant association between the two.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Swami|first=Viren, et all|title=Acceptance of cosmetic surgery and celebrity worship: Evidence of associations among female undergraduates|journal=Personality and Individual Differences|volume=47|issue=8|year=2009|pages=869–872|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0191886909003134|doi=10.1016/j.paid.2009.07.006}}</ref> "[[Celebrity worship]]" is when a person has formed a strong adoration towards a celebrity and sees him or her as a role model. The study shows that this worship is considered a normal aspect of [[self-identity]] as it is usually formed as the identity is being developed. Worship of the celebrity may give people a sense of satisfaction or fulfillment. The study mentions that "'entertainment-social' celebrity worship reflects the social aspects of parasocial attachment, and is driven by an attraction to a favourite celebrity because of their perceived ability to entertain. For some individuals, a compromised identity structure may lead to psychological absorption (intensive and compulsive feelings) with a celebrity, or what has been termed 'Intense-personal' attitudes. In extreme cases, this absorption may become addictive, leading to 'Borderline-pathological' attitudes and behaviours that serve to maintain an individual's satisfaction with the parasocial attachment."
Additionally, this concept of celebrity worship may be used as symbols exemplary of the person's physical ideal. That is, they believe that their physical attractiveness will bring them thinks equal to or similar to the celebrity's level of popularity and exterior happiness. To them, physical attractiveness will bring that happiness, and cosmetic surgery can help them attain this. The study explains that "celebrities may represent prominent and unique social comparison targets, whose physical attractiveness and condition provide information about socially-idealised standards of beauty."
Notably, celebrity worship makes people more prone to [[mental health]] problems such as high levels of [[neuroticism]], [[anxiety]], [[depression (mood)|depression]], and an overall strong sense of worry. Being fixated on how a celebrity looks can increase anxiety because it causes the person to constantly compare themselves to them, thus creating unnecessary worry and high maintenance of their appearance, and eventually depression due to the fact that they cannot look like or be their [[role model]]. These people are likely to seek procedures such as plastic surgery in order to become exaggerated versions of themselves in hopes of becoming as physically appealing as their celebrity role model, and hopefully happier as a result. They consider [[plastic surgery]] a cure, or a fix, for their unhappiness. Therefore, they see it as acceptable.
==The effect of blogs and Internet== Style blogs showcase slender young women posing in the latest fashions. Young girls see these and want to emulate their style. The Thin Ideal comes into play. [[Gwyneth Paltrow]]'s popular lifestyle blog/website Goop is geared towards parents, specifically women. She provides spirituality articles, family meal recipes, glimpses into her Hollywood life, and child-raising tips. Women and mothers read her blog and are consumed by the glamorous appeal. Paltrow advises wardrobe changes every season and provides essential-clothing suggestions that are far out of reach for the average women. [[Nylon Magazine]] is a colorful [[fashion magazine]] for [[pre-teens]] and teenagers who aim to live fashionably. The magazine dispenses beauty advice for how you can look like your favorite television star and promotes expression of style. Its influence is prevalent in the [[blogosphere]]. Young women with blogs take photos of themselves in their daily outfits. They often cite Nylon, among other sources, as one of their influences. Kellner states, "Media images help shape our view of the world and our deepest values: what we consider good or bad, positive or negative, moral or evil. Media stories provide the symbols, myths, and resources through which we constitute a common culture and through the appropriation of which we insert ourselves into this culture."<ref name=Kellner/> Fashion and beauty blogs focus on the values of looking a certain way, or what society deems as "stylish." These websites bring together people with the same goals – i.e. looking good – and cultivate a culture in which the beauty myth is prevalent.
In addition to blogs, social networking cites such as Facebook play a role in media influence. Many celebrities and clothing stores have Facebook profiles in which fans subscribe to receive a constant stream of news from these pages on their Facebook news feeds. Celebrities promote their latest films, television appearance, favorite charities, self-endorsed items, and those who are subscribed to them remain in-the-know and are kept up to date of their glamorous, high-profile words. Clothing stores update their pages with photos of their seasonal collections, showcasing attractive young models dressed in their fashions, thus creating images of desire in their impressionable audiences.

{{Legality of cannabis by US state}} In '''2018''', [[U.S. state]]s proposed or are expected to propose '''cannabis reform legislation''' for [[medical marijuana]] and non-medical adult use. State-level legalization remains at odds with cannabis' status as a [[List of Schedule I drugs (US)|Schedule I narcotic]] under the [[Controlled Substances Act]] at the Federal level, and the [[Cannabis policy of the Donald Trump administration]] appeared to become more hostile than that of the previous administration, with the early January rescission of the [[Cole Memorandum]].
States expected to be most likely to propose legislation to fully legalize include Michigan, New Hampshire, New Jersey, and Rhode Island.<ref name=Lee2018>{{citation|title=Vermont, New Jersey, Michigan? Here are some of the states looking to legalize marijuana in 2018|newspaper=The Los Angeles Times|date=January 8, 2018|author=Kurtis Lee|url=http://www.latimes.com/nation/la-na-marijuana-legalization-2018-htmlstory.html}}</ref> Other possible full legalization states include Connecticut, Delaware, and Ohio; medical marijuana proposals were under way or expected in Oklahoma, Kentucky, South Dakota, and Utah.<ref>{{citation |title=MARIJUANA LEGALIZATION 2018: WHICH STATES MIGHT CONSIDER CANNABIS LAWS THIS YEAR?|author = LINLEY SANDERS |work=Newsweek|date=January 2, 2018|url=http://www.newsweek.com/marijuana-legalization-2018-which-states-will-consider-cannabis-laws-year-755282}}</ref>
==Federal== In the House of Representatives, Democratic Representatives [[Barbara Lee]] of California and Representative [[Ro Khanna]], of the same state, introduced the Marijuana Justice Act, the counterpart of a Senate Bill 1689 which was introduced in 2017 by Senator [[Cory Booker]].<ref>{{citation|title=In rebuff to Sessions, federal Marijuana Justice Act filed in House: This is not just any marijuana legalization bill|author=Phillip Smith|work=[[Salon (website)|Salon]]|date=January 19, 2018|url=https://www.salon.com/2018/01/19/in-rebuff-to-sessions-federal-marijuana-justice-act-filed-in-house/}}</ref><ref>{{citation|title=Marijuana Justice Act of 2017|work=Harvard Law Review|date=January 10, 2018|url=https://harvardlawreview.org/2018/01/marijuana-justice-act-of-2017/}} 131 Harv. L. Rev. 926</ref>
A bipartisan bill, the Sensible Enforcement Of Cannabis Act, was introduced in February.<ref>{{citation|newspaper=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]]|title=Bipartisan bill offered in House to protect marijuana users in legal weed states|author=Lydia Wheeler|date=February 15, 2018 |url=http://thehill.com/regulation/legislation/374130-bipartisan-bill-offered-in-house-to-protect-marijuana-users-in-legal}}</ref>
In late March, Senate Majority Leader [[Mitch McConnell]] announced he would introduce the [[Hemp Farming Act of 2018]]. It would expand the experimental hemp production allowed under the 2014 farm bill, removing hemp from [[List of Schedule I drugs (US)|Schedule I controlled substances]] and making it an ordinary agricultural commodity.<ref>{{citation|title=McConnell announces hemp legislation with Ky. Ag. Commissioner|publisher=[[WKYT-TV]]|location=Lexington, Kentucky|date=March 26, 2018|url=http://www.wkyt.com/content/news/Sen-McConnell-and-Ky-Ag-Commissioner-announce-hemp-legislation-477932893.html}}</ref><ref>{{citation|title=McConnell bill would legalize hemp as agricultural product|author=Morgan Gstalter|date=March 26, 2018 |work=The Hill|url=http://thehill.com/policy/energy-environment/380287-mcconnell-bill-would-legalize-hemp-as-agricultural-product}}</ref><ref>{{citation|title=Senator McConnell and Commissioner Quarles Announce Hemp Legislation|date=March 26, 2018|publisher=United States Senate official website|author=Senator Mitch McConnell|type=press release|url=https://www.mcconnell.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/pressreleases?ID=92CD9FA7-C278-4332-B187-745C15F35EFC}}</ref> He introduced the bill on the Senate floor on April 12.<ref>{{citation|title=Hemp Farming Act of 2018 introduced by Sen. Mitch McConnell|date=April 12, 2018|author= Alicia Wallace| work=[[The Cannabist]]|publisher=''[[The Denver Post]]''| |url=https://www.thecannabist.co/2018/04/12/mcconnell-hemp-farming-act-of-2018/103438/}}</ref>
On April 11, President Donald Trump told Senator [[Cory Gardner]] of Colorado that he would "support congressional efforts to protect states that have legalized marijuana".<ref>{{citation|title=Trump, Gardner strike deal on legalized marijuana, ending standoff over Justice nominees|newspaper=The Washington Post|author=Seung Min Kim| date=April 13, 2018|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/trump-gardner-strike-deal-on-legalized-marijuana-ending-standoff-over-justice-nominees/2018/04/13/2ac3b35a-3f3a-11e8-912d-16c9e9b37800_story.html}}</ref> A bill to resolve the state-Federal conflict was still "a work in progress" but seemed to a Colorado cannabis industry group be implicit in Gardner's comments afterwards.<ref>{{citation|title=President Trump to Cory Gardner: Colorado's legal marijuana won't be targeted by Jeff Sessions, Justice Department|authors=Mark K. Matthews and Alicia Wallace | newspaper=The Denver Post|date=April 13, 2018 |url=https://www.denverpost.com/2018/04/13/trump-gardner-colorado-marijuana-industry-not-targeted/|quote=Gardner's actions could help ensure a stable business climate for the state’s cannabis industry...his legislation-in-waiting would encapsulate many, if not all, of those issues [banking, business tax deductions, and state regulation] brought to Congress in piecemeal.}}</ref> California Senator [[Diane Feinstein]] made a surprising reversal of her prior stance against state or federal legalization in May and said she was "open to supporting" the Gardner bill.<ref>{{citation|title=Sen. Dianne Feinstein says she no longer opposes legal marijuana |author= Keith McMillan |date=May 1, 2018 |newspaper=The Washington Post |url= https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/powerpost/wp/2018/05/01/sen-dianne-feinstein-says-she-no-longer-opposes-legal-marijuana/}}</ref> Gardner and Senator Elizabeth Warren introduced the [[STATES Act]] in June to apply Federal prohibition only in states that did not have state-level legalization.<ref>{{citation|title=Senators announce bill to protect states' ability to make marijuana laws|author=Ali ROGIN |date=Jun 7, 2018|publisher=ABC News|url=https://abcnews.go.com/amp/Politics/senators-announce-bill-protect-states-legalization-marijuana/story?id=55719110}}</ref>
==State== In summary, Vermont passed legislation legalizing cannabis statewide in January, the first time legalization occurred via legislature, not initiative. Utah legalized medical cannabis without THC restrictions for some patients in March. Industrial hemp laws were passed in Alaska, Kansas and Oklahoma in April, and a New Mexico Supreme Court decision ordered the [[promulgation]] of a 2017 hemp bill. Oklahoma legalized medical cannabis in June.
===Alaska=== Senate Bill 6, allowing industrial hemp farming, was passed unanimously by both chambers of the state legislature, with passage in the House occurring on February 19, 2018.<ref>{{citation|title=Alaska Legislature passes bill to legalize industrial hemp|author=Casey Grove|publisher=Alaska Public Media|date=February 21, 2018|url=https://www.alaskapublic.org/2018/02/21/alaska-legislature-passes-bill-to-legalize-industrial-hemp/}}</ref><ref>{{citation|title=AK House unanimously pass bill to legalize industrial hemp|publisher=[[KTVA]]|date=February 19, 2018|url=http://www.ktva.com/story/37541525/ak-house-unanimously-pass-bill-to-legalize-industrial-hemp}}</ref> It was signed into law by the governor on April 13.<ref>https://legiscan.com/AK/bill/SB6/2017</ref>
===Arizona=== An initiative to legalize hemp, defined as cannabis with less than 0.4% THC, was listed by the Secretary of State as a potential November, 2018 ballot measure.<ref>{{citation|title=2018 Initiatives, Referendums & Recalls|publisher=Arizona Secretary of State|accessdate=2018-04-26|url=http://apps.azsos.gov/election/2018/general/initiatives.htm}}</ref><ref>{{citation|title=Arizona Industrial Hemp Initiative (2018)|publisher=Ballotpedia|url=https://ballotpedia.org/Arizona_Industrial_Hemp_Initiative_(2018)}}</ref>
===Colorado=== House Bill 1295 passed both houses of the state legislature, unanimously in the Senate, by April. It would "regulate hemp like any other food ingredient". A provision of the bill prohibits pharmaceutical companies from "interfering" with distribution or sale of naturally occurring (CBD-containing) hemp products.<ref>{{citation|title=Pass the hemp: Colorado prepares to regulate the plant like any other food ingredient|author=Alicia Wallace|date=April 25, 2018|work=The Cannabist|publisher=''The Denver Post''|url=https://www.thecannabist.co/2018/04/25/colorado-hemp-food-ingredient-bill/104230/}}</ref>
===Connecticut=== In April, HB 5394, a bill to "require multiple state agencies to coordinate and develop a plan to legalize and regulate cannabis sales by October 1" was referred from the Appropriations Committee to the state General Assembly.<ref>{{citation|work=Merry Jane|title=Connecticut Legislative Committee Advances Recreational Cannabis Bill|date=April 8, 2018|author=Chris Moore|url=https://merryjane.com/news/connecticut-legislative-committee-advances-recreational-cannabis-bill}}</ref><ref>{{citation|title=Connecticut lawmakers advance marijuana legalization bill|author=JACQUELINE THOMSEN |work=[[TheHill]]|date=April 5, 2018|url=http://thehill.com/homenews/state-watch/381865-connecticut-lawmakers-to-vote-on-marijuana-legalization}}</ref> This was the first time a legalization bill made it out of committee in the Connecticut legislature.<ref>{{citation|newspaper=Hartford Courant|title=Connecticut Legislative Committee Passes Recreational Marijuana Bill|date=April 5, 2018|url=http://www.courant.com/politics/hc-pol-marijuana-legislation-hits-committee-deadline-20180405-story.html|quote=For the first time in the Connecticut legislature, a recreational marijuana bill has made it out of committee and is headed to the full General Assembly for consideration.}}</ref>
===Georgia=== State senator [[Curt Thompson]] introduced SB 344, legislation to legalize cannabis, in January.<ref>{{citation|title=Lawmaker introduces bill to legalize recreational marijuana in Georgia|author= Richard Elliot|date=February 6, 2018|publisher =[[WSB-TV]]|url=http://www.wsbtv.com/news/local/lawmaker-introduces-bill-to-legalize-recreational-marijuana-in-georgia/695390271}}</ref><ref>{{citation|publisher=Georgia General Assembly|title=2017-2018 Regular Session - SB 344 'Georgia Retail Marijuana Code'; regulation of the retail sale of marijuana|url=http://www.legis.ga.gov/legislation/en-us/display/20172018/sb/344}}</ref> Atlanta had decriminalized the substance in 2017.<ref>{{citation|work=Fortune|title=Atlanta Is The Latest U.S. City to Decriminalize Marijuana. Here's What That Means.|author=Grace Donnelly|date= October 3, 2017|url=http://fortune.com/2017/10/03/list-of-cities-that-decriminalized-marijuana/}}</ref>
===Illinois=== Voters in [[Cook County, Illinois|Cook County]] answered 68% "yes" on a March referendum on statewide cannabis legalization.<ref>{{citation|title=Chicago Says It Loud and Clear: Legalize It! Cook County voters overwhelmingly backed a marijuana referendum, and the new Democratic nominee for governor is all-in for reform.|author=John Nichols|url=https://www.thenation.com/article/chicago-says-it-loud-and-clear-legalize-it/}}<!-- 63% in early counts--></ref><ref name=trib0322/> Earlier in March, the state senate had voted 73-13 to approve a bill sponsored by [[William Cunningham (Illinois politician)|Bill Cunningham]], presenting a statewide referendum on legalization in November.<ref>{{citation|title=Illinois Senate Approves Marijuana Ballot Question – The Illinois Senate has approved putting a non-binding question on the November ballot asking voters if Illinois should legalize recreational marijuana.|publisher=Associated Press|via=US News|date=March 1, 2018|url=https://www.usnews.com/news/best-states/illinois/articles/2018-03-01/illinois-senate-approves-marijuana-ballot-question}}</ref>
====Proposed legalized, regulated sales==== {{Further|Cannabis in Illinois#Proposed recreational use (2017)}} SB316 and HB2353, which would create a regulated legalized adult-use system in Illinois, were introduced in 2017 and were still under consideration by the legislature in 2018.<ref>[https://www.usnews.com/news/best-states/illinois/articles/2017-09-06/legislature-hears-pros-cons-on-marijuana-legalization Legislature Hears Pros, Cons on Marijuana Legalization], Associated Press, September 6, 2017</ref><ref name=trib0322>{{citation|newspaper=Chicago Tribune|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/local/breaking/ct-met-marijuana-legalize-illinois-cook-county-20180321-story.html|title=Marijuana referendum could strengthen movement to legalize in Illinois, but naysayers say ballot question unfair|date=March 22, 2018|author=Robert McCoppin}}</ref>
====Hemp==== A hemp bill, SB 2298, passed the state Senate unanimously on April 24. It would remove industrial hemp from the state's legal definition of a drug, and put it under regulation by the state Department of Agriculture.<ref>{{citation|title=Bill to Legalize Industrial Hemp Passes Illinois Senate |author=Alex Ruppenthal | date=April 30, 2018|publisher=[[WTTW]]|url=https://chicagotonight.wttw.com/2018/04/30/bill-legalize-industrial-hemp-passes-illinois-senate}}</ref> The bill passed the state House of Representatives 106-3 on May 25.<ref>{{citation|title=Illinois Governor Gets Bill Legalizing Industrial Hemp|date=May 23, 2018|publisher=WJBD|url=http://www.wjbdradio.com/local-news/2018/05/23/illinois-governor-gets-bill-legalizing-industrial-hemp}}</ref>
===Iowa=== The Iowa state Senate passed File 2398, the "Iowa Industrial Hemp Act", 49-0 on April 4.<ref>{{citation|title=Iowa Senate OKs bill opening door to hemp production, marketing|newspaper=Des Moines Register |author=William Petroski | date= April 4, 2018|url=https://www.desmoinesregister.com/story/news/politics/2018/04/04/iowa-hemp-production-marketing-iowa-senate-legislation-senate-file-2398/484563002/}}</ref>
===Kansas=== In March, Kansas Senate Bill 263, legalizing a hemp research and production pilot under the state's Department of Agriculture in accordance with the Federal 2014 Farm Bill, cleared the state House of Representatives 123 to 1 and the state Senate 36 to 3.<ref>{{citation|title=Kansas House passes industrial hemp bill|newspaper=High Plains/Midwest Ag Journal|date=March 28, 2018|url=http://www.hpj.com/ag_news/kansas-house-passes-industrial-hemp-bill/article_578d7e34-32c4-11e8-98f6-d3ef36abb413.html}}</ref> The bill was signed into law by the governor on April 20.<ref>{{citation|title=KDA prepares to oversee industrial hemp in Kansas|newspaper=High Plains/Midwest Ag Journal|date=Apr 20, 2018|url=http://www.hpj.com/crops/kda-prepares-to-oversee-industrial-hemp-in-kansas/article_59886388-44e5-11e8-af75-6be60b4a4071.html}}</ref><ref>{{citation|title=KDA Prepares to Oversee Industrial Hemp in Kansas|publisher=Kansas Department of Agriculture|type=Press release|date=April 20, 2018|url=http://agriculture.ks.gov/AllNewsItems/2018/04/20/kda-prepares-to-oversee-industrial-hemp-in-kansas}}</ref>
===Massachusetts=== Although Massachusetts legalization of cannabis for recreational use was passed in the 2016 ballot, the purchase of recreation cannabis still is not legal in the state. The Massachusetts state legislature who opposed the ballot question have delayed any openings of recreational dispensaries through additional regulatory means.
===Michigan=== As of January, 2018 a group had submitted over 300,000 signatures for the [[2018 Michigan Marijuana Legalization Initiative]] pending certification by the state for the 2018 general election ballot.<ref name=Lee2018/> The state certified the initiative on April 26.<ref>{{citation|title=It's official: Pot legalization will be on the Michigan ballot this November|author=Violet Ikonomova |date=April 26, 2018|newspaper=[[Detroit Metro Times]]|url=https://www.metrotimes.com/news-hits/archives/2018/04/26/its-official-pot-legalization-will-be-on-the-michigan-ballot-this-november}}</ref> Proposal 1 was approved by voters on November 6, and the Secretary of State certified the election returns as of November 26, and as such, the proposal must become law in Michigan by no later than December 6.
===Missouri=== SB 547 and HB 2034 were introduced to legalize [[hemp farming]]. The senate bill passed on March 15.<ref>{{citation|publisher=Associated Press|title=Missouri Senate passes bill legalizing industrial hemp|date= March 15, 2018|via=US News|url=https://www.usnews.com/news/best-states/missouri/articles/2018-03-15/missouri-senate-passes-bill-for-industrial-hemp-pilot}}</ref><ref>http://www.senate.mo.gov/18info/BTS_Web/Bill.aspx?SessionType=R&BillID=69472168</ref><ref>{{citation|newspaper=St. Louis Post-Dispatch|title=Industrial hemp, medical marijuana proposals interest Missouri lawmakers|author=Marie French|date=April 1, 2018|url=http://www.stltoday.com/news/local/govt-and-politics/industrial-hemp-medical-marijuana-proposals-interest-missouri-lawmakers/article_0c04670f-9a25-5268-b290-01dbef064ce1.html}}</ref>
Several versions of "Missouri Cannabis and Cannabis Hemp Legalization Initiative" were proposed to amend the [[Missouri state constitution]]. Initiative 2018-134 would allow prescription of cannabis by veterinarians.<ref>{{citation|title=Missouri Cannabis and Cannabis Hemp Legalization Initiative (2018) |publisher=Ballotopedia|url=https://ballotpedia.org/Missouri_Cannabis_and_Cannabis_Hemp_Legalization_Initiative_(2018)|accessdate=2018-04-01}}</ref>
On May 1, the state House passed a bill to allow medical cannabis for conditions including cancer and PTSD.<ref>{{citation|title=Missouri House votes to legalize medical marijuana|publisher=Associated Press|via=''The Denver Post''|date= May 1, 2018|url=https://www.denverpost.com/2018/05/01/missouri-house-medical-marijuana/}}</ref>
On May 3, New Approach Missouri and Find the Cure submitted two initiatives to the state for the November ballot. Each would amend the state constitution to allow medical cannabis. Both groups claimed to have conducted independent verification of over 300,000 signatures against the required 160,000.<ref>{{citation|title=Medical Marijuana Groups Submit Signatures for November Vote: Supporters of legalizing medical marijuana in Missouri have turned in signatures for two ballot initiatives that would let voters decide the issue in November|date=May 4, 2018|author=Blake NELSON|publisher=Associated Press|via=US News|url=https://www.usnews.com/news/best-states/missouri/articles/2018-05-04/medical-marijuana-groups-submit-signatures-for-november-vote}}</ref><ref>[https://ballotpedia.org/Missouri_Medical_Marijuana_and_Veteran_Healthcare_Services_Initiative_(2018) Missouri Medical Marijuana and Veteran Healthcare Services Initiative (2018)], Ballotpedia, accessed 2018-05-08</ref><ref>{{citation|title=Medical marijuana advocates get twice the needed signatures for ballot initiative|author=Sarah FENTEM |date=May 4, 2018|publisher=St. Louis Public Radio|url=http://news.stlpublicradio.org/post/medical-marijuana-advocates-get-twice-needed-signatures-ballot-initiative}}</ref>
===New Hampshire=== The New Hampshire state House of Representatives voted to legalize recreational marijuana on January 9. The bill, legalizing possession but not sale, was sent to the Ways and Means committee to hold hearings and study implementation.<ref>{{citation|title=New Hampshire House votes to legalize recreational marijuana|date=January 9, 2018|author=Polly Washburn|publisher=''The Denver Post''|url=https://www.thecannabist.co/2018/01/09/new-hampshire-marijuana-legalization-bill-2/96320/}}</ref><ref>{{citation|publisher=New Hampshire Public Radio|title=Marijuana Legalization Bill Has N.H. House Hearing Today|author=Dan Tuohy|date=February 13, 2018|url=http://nhpr.org/post/marijuana-legalization-bill-has-nh-house-hearing-today}}</ref>
===New Jersey=== On the legislature's opening day, January 9, Senate Bill 830 was introduced by Sen. [[Nicholas Scutari]]. It which would create a legal framework for cannabis sales in the state under a Division of Marijuana Enforcement, and allow personal possession of up to one ounce. Assembly Bill 1348, an identical bill, went to the house.<ref>{{citation|title=N.J. legislator plants seeds for recreational marijuana legalization|author=Justin Auciello|date=January 11, 2018|publisher=[[WHYY-TV|WHYY]]|url=https://whyy.org/articles/n-j-legislator-plants-seeds-for-recreational-marijuana-legalization/}}</ref><ref>{{citation|title= The Path To Legalization: New Jersey’s Pursuit Of Marijuana Reform|author= Cole Schotz|date=March 6, 2018|work=JD Supra |url=http://www.jdsupra.com/legalnews/the-path-to-legalization-new-jersey-s-11601/}}</ref>
In February, a bill decriminalizing possession of 10 grams of cannabis was introduced by a bipartisan group of legislators.<ref>{{citation|title=NJ lawmakers propose decriminalizing small amounts of marijuana instead of legalization|date=February 15, 2018|publisher=Associated Press|via=[[KPIX-TV]]|url=http://pix11.com/2018/02/15/nj-lawmakers-propose-decriminalizing-small-amounts-of-marijuana-instead-of-legalization/}}</ref>
In March, governor [[Phil Murphy]] said he wanted a tax-and-regulate bill passed by the legislature by year's end, and projecting such a measure would pass, included $60 million from cannabis tax revenues in the next year's state budget proposal.<ref>{{citation|title=Phil Murphy wants legal weed law in N.J. by end of year|date=March 13, 2018|publisher=NJ.com|url=http://www.nj.com/marijuana/2018/03/murphy_wants_legal_weed_in_nj_by_end_of_year.html}}</ref><ref>{{citation|newspaper=Philadelpha Inquirer|title=Gov. Murphy's proposed N.J. budget would hike taxes by $1.6 billion|date=March 13, 2018|author=Andrew Seidman|url=http://www.philly.com/philly/news/phil-murphy-tax-plan-budget-new-jersey-20180313.html}}</ref>
===New Mexico=== In April, the [[Albuquerque]] City Council voted to decriminalize possession of one ounce of cannabis.<ref>{{citation|title=Albuquerque City Council votes to decriminalize marijuana |author=Mary Hudetz|publisher=Associated Press|via=Chicago Tribune |date=April 3, 2018|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/lifestyles/health/sns-bc-nm--marijuana-albuquerque-20180403-story.html}}</ref>
In April, the state Supreme Court ruled unconstitutional an earlier governor's veto of two hemp bills that had passed the legislature. It was reported that SB6, which passed 58-8 and 37-2 in the House and Senate respectively, would probably become the basis for state law.<ref>{{citation|title=Industrial Hemp is Coming to New Mexico: State Supreme Court decision legalizes hemp research and cultivation; Ag Department working on rules|newspaper=[[Santa Fe Reporter]]|author=Aaron Cantú|date=April 27, 2018|url=https://www.sfreporter.com/news/2018/04/27/industrial-hemp-is-coming-to-new-mexico/}}</ref><ref>https://legiscan.com/NM/bill/SB6/2017</ref> The state Department of Agriculture commenced rulemaking for a hemp research program at the end of April as authorized by SB6.<ref>{{citation|title=Industrial Hemp Research Program: Senate Bill 6, Industrial Hemp Research|publisher =New Mexico Department of Agriculture|date=April 30, 2018|url=http://www.nmda.nmsu.edu/2017/11/industrial-hemp-research-program/}}</ref>
===North Carolina=== Representative [[Kelly Alexander]] introduced House Bill 944 in May, which would raise the threshold for class one misdemeanor possession of cannabis (carrying jail time penalty) to four ounces, and allow expunging records of those previously convicted of that amount.<ref>{{citation|title=Proposed NC bill would allow some marijuana convictions to be expunged|date= May 25, 2018|publisher=[[WTVD]] "ABC11"|url=http://abc11.com/proposed-nc-bill-would-allow-some-marijuana-convictions-to-be-expunged-/3521148/}}</ref><ref>{{citation|title=New Bill Would Allow North Carolinians To Possess Up To 4 Ounces Of Marijuana|author= Mark Boyle |date=May 26, 2018|publisher =[[WFMY-TV]]|url=https://www.wfmynews2.com/article/news/new-bill-would-allow-north-carolinians-to-possess-up-to-4-ounces-of-marijuana/83-558756849}}</ref>
===Oklahoma=== House Bill 2913, a bill legalizing [[hemp]] production under the "Oklahoma Industrial Hemp Agricultural Pilot Program", passed the state senate unanimously and with one "nay" vote in the state house on April 17.<ref>{{citation|title=Cash crop? Industrial hemp measure heading to Gov. Fallin's desk|date=April 17, 2018 |publisher=[[KFOR-TV]] |url=}}</ref> It was signed into law by the governor on April 25.<ref>{{citation|title=Fallin Signs Bill Legalizing Hemp Pilot Program|date=April 25, 2018|newspaper=Tulsa World|url=http://www.tulsaworld.com/communities/skiatook/news/fallin-signs-bill-legalizing-hemp-pilot-program/article_795ebb5b-75f0-5a56-b224-aefb7e70baaf.html}}</ref>
State Question 788, a statutory initiative creating a legal medical cannabis program, was passed by voters during the June 26, 2018 primary.<ref>{{citation|title=Key Questions And Answers On SQ 788, Oklahoma's Vote On Medical Marijuana |authors= Joe Wertz and Jackie Fortier |date=May 3, 2018|publisher=[[KOSU]]|url=http://kosu.org/post/key-questions-and-answers-sq-788-oklahomas-vote-medical-marijuana}}</ref>
In April, two other initiatives, SQ 796 and SQ 797, qualified for signature gathering in advance of the general election. The latter would legalize adult-use (recreational) cannabis in Oklahoma. Both are proposed constitutional amendments and could not be changed by the state legislature.<ref>{{citation|title=Okla. group cleared to collect signatures to put recreational pot on ballot|publisher=MSN|date=April 30, 2018|url=https://www.msn.com/en-us/finance/news/okla-group-cleared-to-collect-signatures-to-put-recreational-pot-on-ballot/}}</ref>
===Tennessee=== On March 21, the [[Tennessee House of Representatives]]{{'}} Criminal Justice Committee voted 9-2 to approve the Medical Cannabis Only Act of 2018.<ref>{{citation|title=Legalization Bill Passes House Committee |author=Lisa Warren |newspaper=Greenville Sun|date=March 29, 2018|url=https://www.greenevillesun.com/news/local_news/legalization-bill-passes-house-committee/article_1879f22a-bf8d-5044-97ba-b9ddf58fb844.html}}</ref> The state senate killed the bill before the legislature adjourned. An issue of concern was there was no taxation or regulatory system in place under the house proposal.<ref>{{citation|title=Medical Cannabis Bill Dies In State Senate |author=Lisa Warren |newspaper=Greenville Sun|date=April 4, 2018|url=https://www.greenevillesun.com/news/local_news/medical-cannabis-bill-dies-in-state-senate/article_abde79a4-76d0-5338-9d38-62b7df0d4875.html}}</ref>
In June two Republican state senators introduced Tennessee Responsible Use of Medicinal Plants (TRUMP) Act to legalize medical cannabis in Tennessee.<ref>{{citation|title=Tennessee's TRUMP Act aimed at Republican medical cannabis doubters|author=Chris Bundgaard |date= June 29, 2018|publisher=[[WKRN-TV]]|url=https://www.wkrn.com/news/political-news/tennessee-s-trump-act-aimed-at-republican-medical-cannabis-doubters/1274304791}}</ref><ref>{{citation|title=Tennessee lawmakers name medical marijuana bill after Trump |author=Morgan GSTALTER |work=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]]|date=June 28, 2018 |url=http://thehill.com/homenews/state-watch/394570-tennessee-lawmakers-name-medical-marijuana-bill-after-trump}}</ref>
===Utah=== {{further|Utah Medical Cannabis Act initiative}} A group called Utah Patients Coalition filed the {{vanchor|Utah Medical Cannabis Act}} initiative <!--possibly same Act introduced to state leg. in 2016; https://www.utahpatients.org/about/--> in June, 2018.<ref>{{citation|title=Utah Group Files 2018 Medical Marijuana Ballot Initiative – A group of activists and Utah residents with chronic conditions has launched a ballot initiative to ask voters next year to pass a broad medical marijuana law.|author=Michelle L. Price|date=June 26, 2017|via=US News|publisher=Associated Press|url=https://www.usnews.com/news/best-states/utah/articles/2017-06-26/utah-group-files-2018-medical-marijuana-ballot-initiative}}</ref> By the beginning of the year, the group had gathered more than half of the 113,000 signatures required to get an initiative for medical cannabis on the November ballot.<ref>{{citation|title=‘I think it’s gonna happen’ Governor Herbert says of medical marijuana in Utah|publisher=[[KSTU-TV]]|location=Salt Lake City|date=January 3, 2018|url=http://fox13now.com/2018/01/03/i-think-its-gonna-happen-governor-herbert-says-of-medical-marijuana-in-utah/}}</ref> The initiative allows for topicals, [[cannabis oil]], [[cannabis edible]]s and vaping,<ref>{{citation|title=Yes to medical marijuana in Utah, no to smoking it: Here's what Utahns may vote on in 2018|author=Kelly Gifford|newspaper=Salt Lake Tribune|date=June 26, 2017|url=http://archive.sltrib.com/article.php?id=5432195&itype=CMSID}}</ref> but not smoking. Polls in the second half of 2017 showed up to 78% support for the initiative.<ref>{{citation|publisher=[[Ballotpedia]]|title=Utah Medical Marijuana Initiative (2018)|url=https://ballotpedia.org/Utah_Medical_Marijuana_Initiative_(2018)|accessdate=2018-02-22}}</ref>
In February, the state house passed HB 197 as an alternative to the initiative. Under HB 197, the [[Utah Department of Agriculture and Food]] would grow and supply cannabis to patients.<ref>{{citation|title=House passes medical marijuana bill that lets Utah grow weed for terminally ill patients|publisher=KSTU-TV|location=Salt Lake City|date=February 13, 2018|author=Ben WINSLOW|url=http://fox13now.com/2018/02/13/house-passes-medical-marijuana-bill-that-lets-utah-grow-weed-for-terminally-ill-patients/}}</ref> A matching bill, HB 195, is a [[right-to-try law]] for terminally ill patients.<ref name=utahleg195>[https://le.utah.gov/~2018/bills/static/HB0195.html HB 195 bill status], Utah legislature, accessed March 17, 2018</ref> On March 7, the bills were passed "easily" by the state senate,<ref>{{citation|title=Here's What Utah Lawmakers Did In 45 Days|authors= JULIA RITCHEY & NICOLE NIXON |date=March 9, 2018|publisher=[[KUER]]|location=Salt Lake City|url=http://kuer.org/post/heres-what-utah-lawmakers-did-45-days#stream/0}}</ref><ref>{{citation|publisher=Associated Press|via=The Seattle Times|title=Utah lawmakers end busy session as ballot initiatives loom|date=March 8, 2018|url=https://www.seattletimes.com/nation-world/utah-lawmakers-get-schools-deal-but-drop-some-divisive-bills/}}</ref> and on the 15th and 16th the bills were sent to the governor to be signed into law.<ref name=utahleg195/><ref name=utahleg197>[https://le.utah.gov/~2018/bills/static/HB0197.html HB 197 bill status], Utah legislature, accessed March 17, 2018</ref> On March 21, the governor signed HB 195 but not 197.<ref>{{citation|publisher=[[KSL-TV]]|title= Utah governor signs bill allowing medical marijuana use by terminally ill patients|author=Ben Lockhart| date=March 21, 2018|url=https://www.ksl.com/?sid=46285459&nid=148}}</ref>
On March 26, the Lieutenant Governor's office validated 117,000 signatures on the Utah Medical Cannabis Act initiative, enough for it to get on the November ballot.<ref>{{citation|title=It looks like medical marijuana will be on the November ballot in Utah|date=March 26, 2018|author=Ben Winslow|publisher=[[KSTU]] News|location=Salt Lake City|url=http://fox13now.com/2018/03/26/it-looks-like-medical-marijuana-will-be-on-the-november-ballot-in-utah/}}</ref>
===Vermont=== {{main|Cannabis in Vermont}} Vermont legalized cannabis possession by an act of the state legislature, and signed by the governor, on January 22, 2018.
==Territory== The [[CNMI Cannabis Act of 2018]] was introduced to the [[Northern Mariana Islands Commonwealth Legislature]] in 2017, and was passed by the Senate in May, 2018.

The '''Maale people''', (also spelled Male and pronounced Maa-lee), are a small ethnic group of approximately 95,000 located in the [[Southern Nations, Nationalities, and People's Region]] at the border between north and south Omo of [[Ethiopia]].<ref>Van Aswegen, Jacobus. 2008. Language Maintenance and Shift in Ethiopia: The Case of Maale. MA thesis, University of South Africa</ref><ref>D.H. Shinn, T.P. Ofcansky, C. Poutry: Historical dictionary of Ethiopia. 2004. Scarecrow Press. USA</ref>
The Maale people are maintaining [[Maale language|their language]] vigorously, despite exposure to outside pressures and languages.<ref>Aswegen, Kobus van. 2008. The maintenance of Maale in Ethiopia. ''Language Matters : Studies in the Languages of Africa'' 39(1): 29-48.</ref>
==Culture==
Many of the practices related to the women of the Maale have been documented by Thubauville (2010), including the differences between traditional and contemporary practices.
They have a gender role called ''ashtime''. There are opposing scholarly interpretations of the role and significance of this. Epprecht believes that they are [[gender assignment|male assigned at birth]] individuals who behave as women and also have sex with men.<ref>Epprecht, Marc. Heterosexual Africa?: The History of an Idea from the Age of Exploration to the Age of AIDS, p.61-62. Ohio University Press.</ref> But he admits that the description by Donham (who had actually lived and worked among the Maale), is quite different, that the duty of an ''ashtime'' was to allow the king to have sex "protected from even the merest whiff of female sexuality at key moments in the ritual life of the nation".<ref>p. 196. Epprecht, Marc. 2006. “Bisexuality” and the politics of normal in African ethnography. ''Anthropologica'' 48: 187-201.</ref>
